name: Matt Berger
bio: Botanist. Biodiversity fanatic. I find things. Triple Crowner. 12,700+ miles backpacked. Plants and critters. AT12. PCT14&19. AZT15. CDT17. Non-stop.

social_posts.post_text:
Dracophyllum traversii, mountain neinei! This super unique tree is a member of Ericaceae, the blueberry family, and grows in montane habitats in New Zealand. Members of this genus have very monocot-like leaves, looking like a bromeliad, but the flowers are Ericaceae all the way! Unfortunately I didn’t see any blooming, just an old inflorescence. These crazy cool trees can live over 500 years, taking about 100-150 years to reach a mature stage. This species is also deciduous, and the thick leaf litter that piles up beneath them helps suppress faster growing species, giving them a little bit of an edge. Super stoked to keep finding species that I had wanted to see! 

#Dracophyllumtraversii #Dracophyllum #mountainneinei #grasstree #pineappletree #ericaceae #blueberryfamily #floraofnewzealand #newzealandnativeplants #botany #botanizing #flora

I’ve just crossed off my ultimate life list mushroom… Cyttaria gunnii, the beech orange!!! This is one of the coolest mushroom species in the world. Cyttaria is an Ascomycete in its own order, Cyttariales. Look at the crazy shape of these fruiting bodies! They start out as smooth balls, then a membrane over each chamber breaks, opening the cavity and allowing spores to blow out from all directions. This genus is a host-specific parasite of Nothofagus, southern beech. Cyttaria gunnii infects Nothofagus menziesii and forms woody galls on the stems which it then fruits from annually. The fungus doesn’t cause decay in the wood, but appears to just siphon off sugars and nutrients, allowing its host to survive long term. In the forest where I saw this species, it seemed to heavily infect individual trees and then others very lightly and most not at all. The tree I climbed up into (see photo 10 for the happiest me ever) to get these shots was absolutely laden with fruiting bodies! Hundreds of them! The ground was also littered with them as they easily fall off the stems. One of the coolest things about Cyttaria is that it coevolved with Nothofagus, and both of these genera are found in New Zealand, southern Australia and across the Pacific Ocean in Patagonia because these landmasses were connected tens of millions of years ago. Nothofagus also lived on Antarctica, where it originated about 80 million years ago when the earth was much warmer than today until around 10 millions or so years ago when the earth cooled too much for most plants to survive on Antarctica. I’d bet a good deal of money that Cyttaria also once lived on Antarctica’s Nothofagus! Also this thing is apparently edible! I gave it a lick just to see, and it was pretty mild and mushroomy tasting/ smelling. I seriously lost it when I found this. I thought I’d be too early to find any fruiting, but holy hell… it was perfect. I took tons of videos I’ll make about it soon!

#Cyttariagunnii #Cyttaria #Cyttariaceae #Cyttariales #beechorange #southernbeechorange #southernbeech #nothofagusmenziesii #nothofagus #fungi #fungus #mycology #mushrooms #mushroom #fungifanatic #fungifreaks #fungilover #floraofnewzealand

More stunning views from the Aoraki/ Mount Cook area! There isn’t nearly as much time to explore New Zealand throughly as I’d like! Te Araroa is sounding more appealing after seeing the country and getting aquatinted with the flora and fauna! Still have a few more days here, but on the north island now. Then on to Tasmania! 

#aoraki #mountcook #mountcooknationalpark #newzealand #hiking #subalpine #mountains #newzealandpics #valleys #botany #botanizing #floraofnewzealand #flora

Some more Cyttaria action from when I found them the other day!! You kinda hear how stoked I was to see this beautiful and bizarre parasitic mushroom, which only grows on species of Nothofagus, southern beeches, which are endemic to the Southern Hemisphere in temperate climates. These orange golf ball looking mushrooms are also edible! 

#Cyttariagunnii #Cyttaria #Cyttariaceae #Cyttariales #beechorange #southernbeechorange #southernbeech #nothofagusmenziesii #nothofagus #fungi #fungus #mycology #mushrooms #mushroom #fungifanatic #fungifreaks #fungilover #floraofnewzealand

Sticherus cunninghamii, the umbrella fern! This fern is endemic to New Zealand grows in moist, shaded habitat. It is in the forked fern family, Gleicheniaceae, which is a mostly tropical family that often have really cool bilaterally symmetrical fronds. This species has been pretty common and can form huge patches. The fern diversity of New Zealand is so fun to learn about. You can walk around in the lower elevation forests for a mile and see  probably 30 species! 

#Sticheruscunninghamii #Sticherus #Gleicheniaceae #forkedfern #forkedferns #Gleicheniales #fern #ferns #fernsofinstagram #fronds #frond #botany #botanizing #floraofnewzealand

Last day in New Zealand! Was incredible getting to see so much of the South Island and some of the North Island as well! Thanks to @wilderbound for being a good sport and not getting annoyed with my constant plant hunting on our road trip! Such awesome plant life has evolved here during the last 80 million years of isolation. Now onto the next stop, Tasmania! Will being botanizing there with @crime_pays_but_botany_doesnt until mid December and then back to everyone’s favorite state, Ohio. I’ll still be posting NZ flora all winter I’m sure, as well as Tasmanian species! 

#newzealand #newzealandtrip #rivers #river #bluewater #bluerivers #hiking #hiker #flora #floraofnewzealand

Telopea truncata, Tasmanian waratah! The big showy inflorescence of this species brings back memories of all the showy Proteacea that we saw last year in South Africa! Proteaceae is a predominantly southern hemisphere family with very unique and identifiable morphology where each flower has 4 tepals with with anthers on the inside of each which brush against a pollen presenter as the style elongates and bends until it flings free of the tepals. Fun to see a good diversity of Proteaceae again! Such a cool family. 

#Telopeatruncata #Telopea proteaceae #proteales #Tasmanianwaratah #waratah #floraoftasmania #floraofaustralia #tasmanianativeplants #wildflowers #botany #botanizing

The Tasmanian short beaked echidna, Tachyglossus aculeatus setosus! Echidnas are the only mammals on earth other than platypuses that lay eggs!! There are four species of echidna, and all of which can be found on New Guinea, but this species, the short beaked echidna is also found very widespread in Australia, including Tasmania. The females lay one egg per year which is held in a pouch like marsupials. After the egg hatches the young find a milk patch, an area of the abdomen in the pouch that secretes milk. Monotremes don’t have nipples, unlike other mammals. The young, called puggles, live in the pouch until they get too spiny, then live in its mothers burrow. Because the spend lots of time underground, they’ve adapted to tolerate low oxygen levels. They’re also called spiny anteaters because their main prey items are ants and termites which they dig out with their powerful arms and an they have sensitive snouts to smell and detect electrical signals from their prey. They are superb burrowers and dig holes to live in and to hibernate in the cool Tasmanian winters. Monotremes have retained many intermediate features between reptiles and the placental mammals that dominate the earth now. Egg laying is the trait that likely stands out the most, but they also have very low body temperatures (between  86 and 90 degrees Fahrenheit, much lower than other mammals other than platypuses. Their body temp can also drop to about 40 degrees F when in hibernation. Though they have some ancient reptile traits, they’re still very much mammals, the uniting features of all of us being three inner ear bones, hair and of course, mammary glands, which is why mammals are called mammals! So freaking excited to see this animals. I’ve wanted to see one ever since watching Steve Irwin back in the late 1990s. Of those who know me well, you know he is my hero and the reason I am the way I am today. Him and Pokémon. 

#Tachyglossusaculeatussetosus #Tachyglossusaculeatus #Tachyglossus #tasmanianshortbeakedechidna #shortbeakedechidna #echidna #echidnas #mammals #mammal #monotreme #monotremes #egglayingmammal #fauna #animals #wildlife #spinyanteater

Nothofagus gunnii, the deciduous beech! This tree, endemic to alpine and subalpine areas in Tasmania, is the only winter deciduous tree on the entire continent of Australia! I don’t think I’ve ever been so in love with the leaves of a tree species before. The crinkle cut potato chip texture makes such lovely shadows! This small tree (see photo 9 with @crime_pays_but_botany_doesnt for scale) can only grow in regions of high rainfall and little to no fires, as the plants are killed by fire. They usually grow in wet ground or from rock fields with water beneath them where fires can’t propagate. Like the beech of the northern hemisphere, Fagus, they are wind pollinated (see the male flowers in photos 4 and 5) and have fruit in little cupules (see photo 7). Despite looking so similar to Fagus, they’re only related at the order level. This genus and family is such a cool Gondwanan lineage, with species found in Australia, New Zealand, New Caledonia, New Guinea and Chile! Really happy to have seen this uncommon and stunning tree! 

#Nothofagusgunnii #Nothofagus #deciduousbeech #nothofagaceae #southernbeech #tanglefoot #botany #botanizing #floraoftasmania #tasmaniaendemic #tasmanianativeplants #flora #trees #raretrees #leaveonlyleaves #leaves #textures

Diuris sulphurea, the tiger orchid! Australia has proven to have a lot more interesting terrestrial orchids than I imagined, with this one being a stunner in particular! I have many other I’m excited to share, but the photos are on my Sony camera and I’ve lost my card reader. So those will have to wait until I’m back in America! 

#Diurissulphurea #Diuris #tigerorchid #orchids #orchidaceae #orchid #wildorchid #flora #wildflowers #botany #botanizing

Eucalyptus regnans, the largest flowering plant in the world. These massive trees were absolutely awe inspiring. They towered over a hundred feet taller than the surrounding Nothofagus and Atherosperma. No branches until far up the trunks which start out rough and flaky then transition to smooth on high.  This species of Eucalyptus is second only to the coast redwood (Sequoia sempervirens) for the title of worlds tallest tree species, with the tallest living individual topping out at 330 feet tall (100.5 meters tall)! There are also reliable records of historical trees reaching 375 feet tall, just about 4 feet shorter than the tallest redwood! Though they reach these incredible heights, they aren’t as massive as the huge conifers on the tallest tree species list. Still, these trees are over 10 feet in diameter at breast height (DBH). They also have very wide spreading buttresses that you often see in tropical rainforest trees. They do actually grow in the rainforest, but temperate rainforests here in Tasmania. They also don’t live nearly as long as their coniferous counterparts, usually topping out at around 450 years old. Even after living for centuries, these plants depend on fire to reproduce, and they don’t always survive the blaze. They also don’t usually survive the saw, as most of the old growth eucalyptus forests have been cut down and turned into boards, or these days they’re often ground into wood chips for paper…… I think it should be illegal across the entire world to cut any more old growth forests. Eucalyptus regnans is an absurdly fast growing tree, and plantations of it abound, so there should be no reason to cut any more massive trees. So thrilled to have walk around in these woods and seen these mighty, deliciously smelling trees. 

#Eucalyptusregnans #Eucalyptus #myrtaceae #myrtlefamily #angiosperms #tallestangiosperm #tallesttrees #tallesttree #tallestfloweringplant #botany #botanizing #australianmountainash #mountainash #stringygum #largesttree

Microcachrys tetragona, the strawberry pine! This is in fact a conifer, though a podocarp and not a pine! The female cones develop into clusters of bright red arils that look like a strawberry or raspberry and for the same reason, to be eaten by birds and other animals for seed dispersal! I couldn’t help but eating one myself and I can report that they are slightly sweet and crisp until you’re hit with an overwhelming pine resin taste that is a bit too much. Like biting into the resin bubbles on the trunk of a fir! This plant is endemic to western Tasmania where grows in subalpine and alpine moist habitats where it creeps across the ground as a prostrate shrub to avoid the icy winds. This genus is monotypic, with Microcachrys tetragona being the only species. It is a great example of paleoendemism, which is when a taxa was formerly widespread but now exists only in a tiny area. Microcachrys has very distinctive pollen grains that are readily identifiable, and pollen grains fossilize extremely well. Fossilized Microcachrys pollen has been found in Antarctica, New Zealand, Australia, Southern Africa and South America. A once truly cosmopolitan Gondwanan genus! All those millions of years after the breakup of the southern supercontinent, and all other members of its genus went extinct, Microcachrys tetragona continues to exist, in this far off corner of the world, the western half of a remote island on rocky subalpine ridges… so incredibly happy to have met it. 

#Microcachrystetragona #Microcachrys #strawberrypine #creepingpine #podocarp #podocarpaceae #conifers #conifer #floraoftasmania #tasmanianativeplants #botany #botanizing

Ornduffia reniformis, the running marsh flower! This pretty aquatic flower is in the family Menyanthaceae, which may ring a bell to people in the northern hemisphere who are familiar with Menyanthes trifoliata, the bog bean! That species grows in cold alpine and arctic lakeshores throughout North America and Eurasia. There are many more species in the southern hemisphere, like Ornduffia reniformis, which also has the characteristic hairy looking petals. Super cool to find another plant I wanted to see, even if I got my shoes wet and smelly. Always worth it. 

#Ornduffiareniformis #Ornduffia #Menyanthaceae #runningmarshflower #aquaticplants #aquaticplant #floraoftasmania #tasmaniannativeplants #botany #botanizing #aquaticflowers #wetlands

Stenanthemum pimeleoides, propeller plant! This rare species is a matted member of the Ceanothus family, Rhamnaceae! The super cool thing about it is that it has evolved “floral leaves” that are densely covered in white hairs to act as attractants to pollinator, as they are much larger and showier than the plant’s actual tiny petals. What I think is weird is how some of the floral leaves are only half covered in the white hairs and half glabrous. Like many other members of Rhamnaceae, its seeds can live for a long time in the seed bank and then sprout prolifically after fire, until the area becomes crowded out by grasses and shrubs, as the only two individuals we saw were. You gotta love when a plant with petals evolves better petals! 

#Stenanthemumpimeleoides #Stenanthemum #rhamnaceae #propellerplant #botany #botanizing #flora #wildfowers #fireadapted #tasmanianplants #floraoftasmania #fireregime #plants #plantsofinstagram #plantsmakepeoplehappy

Triggerplants in action! This is Stylidium graminifolium, the grass-leaved triggerplant. Members of this genus and family get the common name triggerplants because they have a touch sensitive mechanism for smacking flower visiting insects with the reproductive structure of the plant! This structure, called the floral column, is the stamens and style of the flower fused together. It starts out staminate with two anthers releasing pollen. When the column is triggered in the staminate stage, it smacks insects, dousing them in pollen. The column then resets within about an hour or less depending on the temperature outside. It is then ready for more smacks! After the anthers have fully dehisced and are empty of pollen grains, the style matures, pushing the two anthers out of the way and exposing the fuzzy green stigma which is receptive to pollen. Once in the pistillate stage, an insect visiting the flower will trigger the column and it will smack the pollinator, which is hopefully covered in pollen from nearby plants that have already doused it with their pollen! Thus pollination is achieved! This ingenious mechanism helps prevent self-pollination, and give the offspring a better chance of survival by having good genetic variation. Triggerplants are most abundant and diverse in Australia, where there are a few hundred species, but Tasmania’s most common is by far this species which we’ve seen all over the place. Very entertaining to trigger the plants and watch them in action! 

At the end of the video see how the column starts with two unopened anthers. Then the anthers have opened and released all the pollen and the green stigma begins to show between the anthers. The last image shows a mature stigma ready to receive pollen. 

#Stylidiumgraminifolium #Stylidium #Stylidiaceae #triggerplants #triggerplant #grasstriggerplant #floraofaustralia #nature #plantsofinstagram #plantsmakepeoplehappy #wildflowers #plantmovement #flora

Xanthorrhoea australis, the austral grass tree! Finally got to see my first grass tree up in northeastern Tasmania along the coast! Grass trees aren’t grasses at all but are in the same family as aloe! They’re fire adapted, and usually flower once a wildfire has burned away the competition and released nutrients into the soil. The bases of the old dead leaves are so densely packed that they provide a lot of thermal insulation to the meristem of the plant during fires. Their huge inflorescence is packed with tiny flowers that don’t smell so good to humans, but apparently great to many insects like flies, beetles, ants etc. This entire genus is endemic to Australia, with about 30 species, some which can grow tall trunks several meters high. I hope to see some of the other species next time I visit Australia! 

#Xanthorrhoeaaustralis #Xanthorrhoea #Asphodelaceae #asparagales #grasstree #grasstrees #Xanthorrhoeoideae #australgrasstree #monocots #botanizing #botany #floraoftasmania #tasmanianativeplants

Blandfordia punicea, Tasmanian Christmas bells! This beautiful wildflower is endemic to western Tasmania at higher elevations in waterlogged heathlands. It is one of just four members of its family, Blandfordiaceae, the others all being in the genus Blandfordia and they’re endemic to eastern Australia. The flowers remind me of Aloe flowers, which seem very out of place in this soaking wet, cold subalpine habitat! They are only distantly related, being in the same order. This was quite the day of botanizing yesterday, with lots of cool Tasmanian endemics seen, but with weather that switched between icy wind blasted sleet to sunny then back to sleet about half a dozen times in several hours. Great to see more plant families I’d never heard of! 

#Blandfordiapunicea #Blandfordia #blandfordiaceae #asparagales #christmasbells #tasmanianchristmasbells #christmasflowers #botany botanizing #wildfowers #floraoftasmania #tasmaniaendemic

Dracophyllum milliganii! This alpine Ericaceae is really stunning on the windswept alpine ridges of southwest Tasmania! The whole inflorescence is a bright pink color, being showier than the flowers themselves! The whole splash of color on the landscape serves to attract pollinators to the plant’s flowers. Another interesting adaptation to flag down pollinators with modified plant parts that aren’t the actual flowers! As long as it works! This ridge was absolutely packed with awesome plant species, many of which I still need to feature, but this one was really stunning in its weirdness and coloration! Sick… 

#Dracophyllummilliganii #Dracophyllum #Ericaceae #Ericales #flora #botany #botanizing #wildflowers #alpineflowers #alpineplants #blueberryfamily #tasmanianplants

The Tasmanian pademelon (Thylogale billardierii)! This adorable critter is a macropod, in the same family as kangaroos and wallabies, though they are generally much smaller. Tasmanian pademelons are only a few feet tall and weigh between 10 and 15 lbs. Like kangaroos, they bounce around on their big hind legs and feed on vegetation. They’re mostly nocturnal, and were one of the main prey items for the Thylacine, which went extinct in just the last 86 years or so, with the last living individual dying in a zoo Hobart in 1936. There are some compelling clues that it may have persisted until the 1960s, but no photographs, bodies or DNA evidence has been uncovered. There’s always a little hope it is still out there, but it’s pretty certain that the Thylacine is really extinct. Now the pademelon is mostly hunted by Tasmanian devils, quolls and eagles. Now that I’m home I can upload my animal photos from my camera, so I will have many more critter photos to come! 

#Thylogalebillardierii #Thylogale #tasmanianpademelon #tasmanianfauna #marsupial #marsupials #marsupialsofinstagram #redbelliedpademelon #animals #mammals #mammalsofinstagram #cute #cuteanimals

Isophysis tasmanica, one of the weirdest and oldest members of the Iris family, Iridaceae! A western Tasmanian endemic, it sits way out on a lonely branch near the base of the Iris family tree in its own subfamily, Isophysidoideae. It is the only member of the Iris family that has a superior ovary (see photo 6), though it has the typical fan like leaf arrangement of irises. It was growing prolifically on a wet subalpine ridge that had recently burned, with some robust plants having dozens of flowers! This plant, while not rare, is often difficult to observe because it grows in habitat that is generally difficult to access in remote wilderness areas of southwestern Tasmania far from any roads, except for a few locations such as this where it can be hiked to in an hour or so. This was one of our main target plants that we wanted to see in our trip to Tasmania, and I was super stoked to see it. The flowers were much larger than I had expected, and the maroon tepal color is pretty distinctive! Such a cool plant! 

#Isophysistasmanica #Isophysis #iridaceae #iris #isophysidoideae #ancientlineage #phylogeny #taxonomy #botanizing #botany #botanyisbitchin #floraoftasmania #tasmanianativeplants

Caladenia dilatata, the green-comb spider orchid! This cool orchid, like many other orchids use a method of attracting insect pollinators called pseduocopulation. The flowers releases chemicals similar to the sex pheromones of females wasps, in this case wasps in the family Thynnidae. The male wasps smell the pheromones and see a vaguely waspy looking flower and attempt to mate with it. In their confusion they get the pollen sacs (pollinia) stuck to their heads and when the jig is up, the wasp flies off sadder, but none the wiser as they are tricked again by another flower, and in the process off attempting to mate with it, transfer the pollen sacs, thus fertilizing the flower! This strategy lets the plant conserve energy by not having to produce energy and water costly nectar to entice insects, but instead minutely produced pheromones and flower shape. Orchids are the masters at pollinator manipulation! So cool! 

#Caladeniadilatata #Caladenia #orchid #orchidaceae #orchidsofinstagram #orchids #botany #botanizing #flora #australianorchids #wildflowers #flowers #ecology #plantsofinstagram #thynnidae #Diurideae

Callitris is a genus of trees in the cypress family (Cupressaceae) that are found in Australia and New Caledonia. Tasmania has two species, both of which can be found in the drier eastern part of the island. Like many Cupressaceae, these species are adapted to bushfires. Their cones do not open and stay on the trees for years and accumulate. They have resinous foliage and burst into flame easily, especially when growing among other flammable plants like eucalyptus. Although the fires kill the parent trees, their thick and knobby cones survive and open up after the heat of a burn and release the seeds into a now competition free landscape, at least until the Eucalyptus regenerate too. It’s an interesting and very successful survival strategy. Many fire adapted plants actively encourage fires to kill themselves via resinous leaves and wood, or stringy bark that acts like kindling to feed fires. As long as their seeds survive the burn, establish and outcompete other vegetation and grow to a reproductive age before burning again, the strategy is evolutionarily successful! It seems crazy, but many familiar plants depend on it: manzanitas, Banksia, and many conifers use this fire encouraging behavior to get a competitive edge for their offspring. Nature is freakin cool. 

Here are the two species of Callitris found in Tasmania.

Photos 1-5: Callitris rhomboidea

Photos 6-10: Callitris oblonga

#Callitris #callitrisrhomboidea #callitrisoblonga #cupressaceae #cupressales #tasmaniacypresspine #cypresspine #conifers #conifer #cones #botany #botanizing #trees #deserttrees

The flying duck orchid (Caleana major)!!! This legendary orchid obviously gets it common name from the incredible resemblance it has to a duck in flight! The flower shape seems incredible to humans, but is even more enticing for the insects that it lures in. This species, like many other orchids, use pseudocopulation to get pollinated. Specific species of wasps are attracted to the labellum (in this species, the duck head looking petal) which emits the sex pheromones of its wasp pollinators. The labellum smells right and looks waspy enough for male wasps that they land on and try to copulate with it! When they do this though, the labellum swings down and traps the wasp in the flower where the pollen sacs are (see photo 2 where I have triggered the mechanism and the labellum is swung down). The wasps get the pollen sacs stuck to their bodies in their struggle to escape. When they finally free themselves they fly off in search of real mates, but apparently are none the wiser and will often be tricked by another duck orchid. When they get trapped in a second flower, the pollen sacs attached to them stick to the stigma and pollination is achieved! Best of luck to the bamboozled male wasps in their search for actual females. Their relentless horniness over geologic time periods is to thank for the awesome duck orchid flower shape we see today. Thanks wasps… Thwasps. 

#Caleanamajor #Caleana #duckorchid #flyingduckorchid #orchids #orchid #orchidaceae #orchidsofinstagram #orchidlover #botany #botanizing #nature #plants #plantsofinstagram

Phlegmariurus varius, the hanging clubmoss!!! This super cool lycophyte was pretty common in the rainforests of New Zealand where it usually grows as an epiphyte on trees, especially tree ferns due to their trunks being very rough and water absorbent. The genus Phlegmariurus is closely related to Huperzia and is sometimes included in that genus. I was super excited to see Al the weird Lycophytes in the temperate southern hemisphere. Some are very different than what we have in North America. There is this hanging epiphytic growth form as well as vines and bushy plants several feet tall! This one is my favorite though. Just so very different and showy! 

#Phlegmariurusvarius #Phlegmariurus #lycophytes #lycophyte #Lycopodiaceae #Lycopodiales #hangingclubmoss #clubmoss #plantsofig #vascularplant #ecology #epiphyte #epiphytes

Aciphylla scott-thomsonii, the giant spaniard… New Zealand’s ultimate Apiaceae. This was one of the most astonishing and beautiful plants I’ve ever had the privilege to observe. Bright glaucous blue spear like foliage, ice crystal needle-like flower bracts surrounding huge bunches of yellow flowers. These stood about 6 feet tall, though can reach up to 9 feet, growing in the rocky wet meadows surrounding New Zealand’s highest glacier encrusted peaks. This is what can happen to humble carrot family members when isolated on islands and put under selection pressure from gigantic herbivorous birds. Incredibly, the lineage that contains the genus Aciphylla (tribe Aciphylleae) contains mostly small ordinary looking parsley-herbs. Genera like Anistome, Gingidia and others, all endemic to New Zealand and a few on nearby temperate southeast Australia. Despite looking so vastly different, some of the large leathery Aciphylla species can form intergeneric hybrids with members of the small herbaceous genus Anisotome. It always blows my mind that humble little herbaceous plants have the capacity to evolve into strange forms on islands where selection pressures are often very different from their mainland ancestors. In the presence of only large avian herbivores, a parsley-like plant can become a huge, spiny, leathery thing like Aciphylla, or more commonly, into shrub or tree forms on islands lacking any large herbivores. I wish I could travel forward into time after humans are extinct to see what all the isolated populations of dandelions and other weeds we introduced to all the words oceanic islands will evolve into. 

#Aciphyllascottthomsonii #Aciphylla #giantspaniard #apiaceaea #umbilliferae #carrotfamily #botany #botanizing #botanist #floraofnewzealand #newzealandnativeplants #islandgigantism #plants #plantsofinstagram #ecology #phylogeny

Being in Australia and New Zealand was a nice way to see some of the more obscure plant families in the order Apiales, as well as many in the more familiar families Apiaceae and Araliaceae! Apiales appears to have originated in what is now Australasia around 117 million years ago, and that region, especially New Zealand, Australia and New Caledonia, is still where most of the families are found, though Araliaceae is found on all continents except Antarctica and Apiaceae has thoroughly conquered the entire world, being found on almost every large landmass on earth and even most oceanic islands. Apiales contains 7 families, 5 of which are showcased here: Pittosporaceae, Griseliniaceae, Pennantiaceae, Araliaceae and Apiaceae. The other two which I haven’t seen are Torricelliaceae and Myodocarpaceae. 

Here are the some examples I saw on the trip! 

1. Pittosporum bicolor (Pittosporaceae)
2. Griselinia littoralis (Griseliniaceae)
3. Pennantia corymbosa (Pennantiaceae)
4. Oplopanax horridus (Araliaceae)
5. Gingidia montana (Apiaceae)

Thismia rodwayi, the fairy lantern! Thismia is one of those genera that has a mysterious, legendary feel to it. Finding one is like seeing a unicorn or something. They’re pretty rare where they do occur, and even when in the right habitat you still have to actually spot one! The whole flower is less than a centimeter long and is usually nestled down in the duff of the forest floor. Thismia are mycoheterotrophic plants, which mean they get all their energy and nutrients by parasitizing a fungus in the soil by tapping into their mycelium. Because it has no need to photosynthesize, it has lost functioning leaves and green coloration. The pollinators of these weird small flowers are still unknown and how they attract them is unknown. The flowers are often under leaves or hidden in the duff, though they could be seen by their orange coloration. I tried sniffing the flowers, but couldn’t detect anything but the smell of soil. The genus Thismia is now known mostly from the tropics and subtropics, but there was a now infamous species, Thismia americana, that somehow existed in a small area of wetlands near Chicago, Illinois, thousands and thousands of miles from the next nearest species in Central America. It was first collected in 1912, then formally described in 1914, then seen in 1916 one last time and never again. It is almost certainly extinct as its entire habitat has been annihilated. It is now an industrial neighborhood of Chicago. It has disappeared forever due to the number one cause of plant and animal extinctions. It is not over-collection, pollution, climate change, or even invasive species, but habitat destruction. Of course all of those factors can work in concert against a species. The best way to save endangered species is to preserve large areas of their habitat. They depend on the whole ecosystem of plants, fungi, insect and bird pollinators, etc. to survive and flourish. Exsitu conservation is important, but not as important as preserving intact habitats. Let’s not let it happen again!

Lepidothamnus laxifolius, the pygmy pine. The smallest conifer in the world!!! This mature, cone producing individual was barely larger than the moss it was growing from. The cone bearing shoots were only about an inch (2.5ish cm) tall… This species is not a pine at all, but an alpine podocarp, a group of mainly southern conifers. This individual is particularly dwarfed by its exposed alpine habitat, but is a fully grown and reproducing plant! In more sheltered areas they can grow about a foot or so tall. It’s pretty freaking cool to see this species and then compare it to the largest plants in the world like sequoias and redwoods and know that despite their unbelievable differences in size, they’re all still conifers!

Dawsonia superba, the giant moss! This is the worlds tallest self supported species of moss! This species can grow over 2 feet tall (about 60 cm)! The individuals that I found were much smaller than that, topping out at about a foot tall (30ish cm) which is still pretty damn tall for a moss! It has evolved its own form of vascular tissue, which is usually absent in mosses, which move water and nutrients up (hydroid cells) and sugars down (leptoid cells) to the lower parts of the plant. This rudimentary vascular system allows the moss to grow so large! It took a long time of searching for this big moss, which is widespread, but apparently uncommon in many places. It is found in New Zealand, where I saw it, as well as eastern Australia, New Guinea and Malaysia. Pretty cool seeing many of the superlative plant species on this trip!

Time for an experiment I’ve always wanted to do! Playing with the extremely hydrophobic spores of clubmosses! These spores can be collected and go by the name Lycopodium powder, named for species in the genus Lycopodium, but the powdery spores of various clubmoss genera also go by the same name because they behave essentially the same.
In this case, I found a huge patch of the very common Diphasiastrum digitatum, the fan clubmoss, and collected some of the strobili (spore producing structures). I took these home and let them dry out more so they’d release their spores. Then yesterday, 3 months after I collected I finally got around to doing the fun part! Screening the spores and isolating them from the chaff. With millions of spores now ready to play with, I took a tablespoon or so of them and sprinkled them into a glass of water. The spores are extremely hydrophobic so they float on the top of the water without wetting. Then the really cool part happens when I dip my fingers into the water… the spores coat my fingers and create a hydrophobic barrier around them! You can see trapped air creating a sheen on the outside of the coating where the spores will not allow water to touch them. Then when I remove my fingers from the water they are completely dry!!! It’s a pretty neat little experiment, and definitely feels trippy! You can feel the cold and pressure of the water on your skin, but they aren’t getting wet at all! The clubmoss spores are very high in fat content, which helps the baby clubmoss grow when the spores germinate, but this also makes the spores hydrophobic… and extremely flammable! So stay tuned for the next post! 😁

#Diphasiastrumdigitatum #Diphasiastrum #lycopodiumpowder #lycopodium #lycophytes #lycophyte #clubmoss #clubmossspores #spores #fanclubmoss #groundcedar #botany #botanizing #science #scienceexperiment #nature #plantsmakepeoplehappy

More fun with Lycopodium powder! This time exploring the explosive side of clubmoss spores! The huge surface area, high fat content and ability to become aerosolized leads to clubmoss spores being capable of creating dust explosions! When the powder is blown into the air near a flame, if the spore to air ratio is right, the spores will explode in a bright and hot flash! I tried this several times and the spores just sort of sparked and fizzled, but this time I got the ratio right and the explosion was much bigger than I expected! Ideally you’d do this over a candle (outside obviously) but I didn’t have any and I had my stove handy and figured it’d work, but with the size of the burst, it’s clearly not safe or smart with a pressurized fuel can nearby! Do not do what I did! I’m dumb! The bright flash of the dust explosion was used historically as an early form of flash photography, but these days it has found a use to make relatively safe and showy flares by magicians and in cinematic special effects! So that’s a pretty unusual use for a common woodland plant! 

#lycopodiumpowder #clubmosses #botanical #botany #diphasiastrumdigitatum #clubmoss #plants #plantsofinstagram #plantlife #science #scienceexperiment #dustexplosion #aerosol #lycophyta #flames #botanizing

Hymenophyllaceae, the filmy ferns are a really cool family of ferns that are very distinctive. They are usually small (though some of the species I saw had fronds up to a foot long), epiphytic and have fronds that are usually only one cell thick! Because of this they typically grow in tropical or temperate rainforests or near waterfalls or other sources of permanent spraying or dripping. There are about 650 species in the family, but they’re not commonly seen in the continental US as there are only a handful of species, and these are typically uncommon. New Zealand is rainy enough that it boasts around 25 species, which are mostly epiphytic, especially on tree fern trunks where there are often several filmy fern species growing together. Due to them growing in dark wet forests, my photos are pretty grainy, but still worth seeing! 

Here are 10 of the filmy ferns I saw while I was in the rainforests of New Zealand!! 

1. Hymenophyllum flabellatum
2. Hymenophyllum villosum

Piper excelsum, kawakawa, is a really cool member of Piperaceae, a mostly tropical family that we don’t really get much in the US other than Hawaii and southern Florida. Piper is a genus that you are certainly familiar with even if you didn’t know it, because it is the same genus that black pepper comes from! Piper excelsum is a pretty large plant for the family too, growing to about 20 feet tall and usually grows as a small tree or shrub. You may be familiar with another genus, Peperomia, which has many species in cultivation as houseplants because some can tolerant low light levels. New Zealand while not really being tropical, has areas that have a Mediterranean climate and where it remains above freezing most of the year, so members of tropical genera can survive and evolve here!

Eucnide rupestris, rock nettle! What a cool rare plant (CRPR 2B.2) with unique yellow and green flowers! Despite its common name, it is not related to true nettles at all, but is in the Mentzelia family, Loasaceae. Like nettles however, this plant does have stinging hairs. To test this I had to really slap my hand around in the plant for maybe 10 seconds before I finally got a single sting that made a small raised bump for a few minutes that itched a little. The sting is very mild, far less painful than stinging nettles or of the other stinging desert plant, Tragia, in the family Euphorbiaceae. Stoked to finally see this plant after a failed search for it almost exactly 3 years ago. It’s a little bit picky about growing conditions, usually only sprouting after a good summer monsoon season and then blooms in the middle of winter. Even though many other plants in the area were blooming 3 years ago, there wasn’t enough summer rain for seeds to sprout so it was completely absent. This year though there were tons of this plant growing from cliff faces and steep rocky outcrops! Really happy to see this cool species!

Antirrhinum confertiflorum, previously Mohavea confertiflora, the ghost flower! This beautiful desert annual can be found in the Southern California deserts in washes and rocky slopes. Its flowers mimic those of Mentzelia involucrata (see photo 3) with which it often grows. Mentzelia have a nectar reward for pollinating bees, but Antirrhinum confertiflorum produces no nectar, thus tricking bees into thinking they will get a tasty treat, but instead leave hungry, but covered in pollen! When the bee is duped by another flower, pollination occurs! This means the ghost flower gets pollinated without having to produce sugar and water costly nectar, resources which can then be used to produce more flowers and seeds instead! A clever deception.

Washingtonia filifera, the California fan palm! This is the only palm native to California as well as the entire western United States. It is a relictual species, thought to have once been much more widespread during wetter time periods such as the most recent ice ages. Now it is mostly found in highly disjunct pockets throughout the deserts of southern California, tiny parts of Arizona and Baja California (see range map in photo 10). They typically grow at isolated springs in canyons, or where ground water is shallow or sometimes on the edges of creeks. The individual populations are usually extremely small, often consisting of just a few to a few dozen individual trees. Because of this there are place names that reference the number of trees such as the city of Twentynine Palms, Seventeen Palms Oasis, Five Palms Spring, and of course the large but unnumbered city of Palm Springs, CA. Obviously palms don’t live forever, and the number of palms at specific locations change over time, so these names were inaccurate almost as soon as coined. They are thought to live up to about 250 years. This species is very tough for a palm. They can withstand the intense heat of the desert, as well as temps to 15°F. They are also well adapted to fire, with their whole skirt of fronds, dead and alive burning away and charring the trunks, only to resprout from the top (see the charred trunks in photo 3). They usually seem to meet their end in flash flood events, which can tear down steep canyons and killed a few of the trees in this grove within the last year. This grove is in a fairly remote backcountry area and it was super cool to hike all the way up into this canyon and not see any other hikers the whole time, even on a weekend! You can feel that these oases in the desert are such special places. The shade they provide is the most you’ll find anywhere in the desert, and the palm fronds provide habitat and shelter to all kinds of birds and other critters. When plant hunting, never underestimate the power of satellite imagery, because you can see large plants from cameras in space such as these palms (see photo 9)! Really neat to target them this way and then hike out to them!

The silver tree fern or ponga (Cyathea dealbata) is a medium sized tree fern growing to about 35 feet tall with fronds almost 15 feet long. It is endemic to New Zealand where it is one of the most iconic plants. The massive unfurling fiddleheads are the basis for the koru symbol in Māori culture. As a lover of ferns, I was blown away by the sight of these massive fiddleheads unfurling in the shady forests of the North Island! Really spectacular to see, and this isn’t even the largest tree fern in New Zealand! Cyathea medullaris, the black tree fern grows over 60 feet tall! But that’s for another post. Growing up in a region completely devoid of tree ferns they’ve always had an extremely ancient and exotic quality in my imagination, so to see them in real life was very moving.

Mentzelia involucrata, the white-bract blazing star! This common Mentzelia has huge flowers with delicate, satiny petals. These flowers are often only partially open, so I splayed it a bit to get a better look at all of the flower’s parts in one shot. This species is in the Mentzelia section Bicuspidaria, which is characterized by having filaments which are two-lobed at the tip (see photo 3) and the anther poking out between the lobes. It is easily distinguished from other members of this section by the white patches on its bracts (see photo 6) and is where it gets its common name. Always nice to see this giant flowered annual in rocky washes and slopes during the desert spring!

Chamaebatia australis, southern mountain misery! This is the rare (CRPR 4.2) southern sister species to the much more abundant and widespread Sierran species Chamaebatia foliolosa. These two species are the only members of the genus Chamaebatia, and despite looking like another similarly named plant, Chamaebatiaria millefolium, they are not closely related. Chamaebatia australis is found in southern San Diego County in the US and across the Mexican border in Baja California. It is a member of the rose subfamily Dryadoideae, which contains just four genera: Chamaebatia, Cercocarpus, Purshia and Dryas. All of these genera contain nitrogen fixing bacteria in their roots, a synapomorphy of the subfamily. I was really in love with this plant when I first saw it the other day. It seems generally taller than the Sierran species with much narrower leaves. That fern-like appearance of the leaves is just so cool. The common name Mountain misery comes from the fact that Chamaebatia usually grows in dense thickets and is covered in sticky resin glands that rub off on clothing, making them filthy, but pretty nice smelling honestly. The smell is also very hard to remove even with multiple washings, so it kinda becomes a pretty pleasant permanent plant perfume.

Adolphia californica, California Adolphia (common names are dumb). This cool and rare (CRPR 2B.1) shrub is related Ceanothus, and the individual flowers are very similar looking, though not arranged in as tight clusters as Ceanothus. It is found only in coastal scrub and chaparral in San Diego County in the US but is more widespread in Baja California. Now this plant made me go down an unfortunate rabbit hole. Maybe you know where I’m going from here. Let’s just all agree that the name Adolph has gone out of fashion. So I looked up who this genus was named after expecting the worst but hoping for better. Luckily it is named after Adolphe-Théodore Brongniart, the “father of paleobotany” and expert in Rhamnaceae. BUT THEN… I had to know. You just know there had to be some fuck out there who named a species after Hitler. Though no plants are, sure as shit there is a beetle named after him. Anophthalmus hitleri… Hitler’s eyeless beetle… a blind cave beetle native to a handful of caves in Slovenia. But it gets worse… this already rare beetle is now threatened with extinction by people who collect and sell it to… ugh… Hitler memorabilia collectors… 

This concludes today’s tale of depravity.

Asclepias albicans, the whitestem milkweed! This is a real special one, it is a 10 foot tall, stem photosynthetic shrub that grows on rocky hillsides and gravelly washes in the Southern California deserts! It does have small ephemeral leaves when young and if it has rained a lot, but otherwise lives its life leafless, and photosynthesizes via its numerous waxy green stems! The beautiful typically shaped milkweed flowers bloom from the tops of the tall woody stems. A real oddball in the Asclepias world! It does have a close relative, Asclepias subulata, that is similarly stem photosynthetic and overlaps in much of its range, but it is much shorter, with more stems and has larger individual flowers. Always a really cool species to see!

Eremalche rotundifolia, desert fivespot! One of the cheeriest of the spring flowers in the Mojave and Sonoran deserts! It is a small annual member of the hibiscus family, Malvaceae! Other familiar members of Malvaceae are cotton, chocolate, okra and durian! Desert fivespot flowers are usually only partially open, and peering down into them you’ll often see lots of little native bees resting in them. I think the bowl shaped flowers are pretty neat, but the pink and red color pattern on top makes them one of the best of the desert annuals!

Salvia greatae, Orocopia sage! This rare (CRPR 1B.3) sage has a very small geographic range in the mountains to the north of the Salton Sea, which is a little puzzling because its habitat of gravelly areas and alluvial fans is extremely common throughout all the deserts of North America. It’s hard to say why it hasn’t dispersed and become more widespread. It is also the clear sister species of Salvia funerea, the Death Valley sage, which is a limestone endemic found in the Mojave desert, mostly in Death Valley. It closely resembles this species in gestalt, but with greener and way meaner leaves! These are spiny as hell! I love the way some of the leaf lobe tips are bent backwards under the leaf making it spiny in all directions (see photo 4)! Like most Salvias it had a really nice smell and I had expected to be similar to Salvia funerea, but it was very different. Wish I had a time machine to see what their most recent common ancestor looked and smelled like and know when it existed!

Hibiscus denudatus, rock hibiscus! This is a small desert Hibiscus that is well adapted to high temperatures and low rainfall. It is widespread in the hotter deserts of North America like the Colorado Desert (part of the Sonoran), the Sonoran and Chihuahua deserts. Probably not areas you’d envision Hibiscus to be be growing! Many members of Malvaceae, such as Hibiscus, have their stamens fused into a tube that surrounds the style, with the stigma lobes poking up just through the top! The bright light made it possible for me to get some real nice macro shots of this. Photos from after the storm. I knew it was going to be a big one so I made sure to get into the park and experience it firsthand. It rained steadily non-stop for almost an entire night and day. Enough rain fell to get all the washes going, but not raging. A deep soak into all the soil here. The runoff from the washes was great enough that it reached Panamint Dry Lakebed and filled up parts of it! Thus a temporary version of the Pleistocene Lake Panamint has been revived! This happens from time to time during heavy rain periods in Death Valley, and is actually the third time the lakebed has held water in the last year. It filled temporarily from summer monsoons, then again with the atmospheric rivers a month or two ago, and then with this storm. The lake is very shallow and usually only a few inches deep, so it doesn’t last long before it dries up again. It made for photo opportunities that I couldn’t resist! Nice reflective lake photos in Death Valley National Park!? The snow clad mountains are an incredible sight too. The snow level was just over 2000 feet in some places, though that melted out very fast. Higher elevations got some very nice deep snow that is going to allow a lot of water to seep into the soil. A lot of mid to high elevation plants should be in great shape this year, but before I get bombarded with superbloom questions, it’s not likely going to be a thing this year in our area. Low elevations were pretty dry in most parts. The last two photos were taken before the storm for some comparison shots. Lake Panamint was filled during wet periods of the Pleistocene ultimately from the Owens River which filled Owens Lake which overflowed into China Lake which overflowed into Searles Lake which overflowed into Lake Panamint. Lake Panamint could reach almost 1000 feet deep and itself overflowed at Wingate Pass into Death Valley to fill Lake Manly. Really cool experience to see Panamint Valley filled with fog and mist all day with an intense smell of creosote in the cold clean air.

Lake Panamint, a rare ephemeral version of the Pleistocene Lake Panamint that was ultimately filled by the Owens River, and which sometimes overflowed into Death Valley to fill Lake Manly. During rainy years or after intense storms, enough runoff pours out of the surrounding mountain ranges and fills the dry lakebed to a shallow depth in parts. Because it is so shallow, the lake usually only remains for a couple weeks or so before evaporating and absorbing into the ground. A very neat sight to see!

Myriopteris newberryi, Newberry's lip fern! This beautiful xeric fern is native to Southern California in where it is usually seen growing from the bases of boulders where it can get a little extra shade as well as the runoff from water that runs down the boulders during rainstorms. Anulocaulis annulatus, valley ringstem! This awesome plant is almost endemic to Death Valley National Park where it is found in washes, rocky slopes and roadsides. It gets its scientific and common names from the conspicuous rings on its stems! These rings are really interesting as they are extremely sticky and are thought to be a defensive mechanism against insect pests. The sticky patches are made of a mix of mucilage, proteins and phenolic compounds that stay very sticky no matter how wet or dry it has been, and this plant grows in Death Valley, so it is obviously super dry most of the time. The rings prevent crawling insects like aphids, ants, caterpillars and other from walking up the stems to reach tasty plant parts and also sequesters damage to a single internode by insects that got to the plant by adults flying and then laying eggs on that section of the plant. Though it seems to be a defense against terrestrial insects, an awful lot of flies seem to get stuck to the rings, a lot more than chance would seem to suggest, so maybe they’re attracted to the rings. I’m sure by now you’re thinking, “is it carnivorous?!” A reasonable thought, but desert plants aren’t really at a lack of nutrients in the soil, so there doesn’t seem to be a need to get mineral nutrients from insect bodies. I don’t think there are any documented cases of carnivorous desert plants, but you never know! Some sticky plants have been documented to trap small insects that predatory insects can then come and easily pick off. These recruited predators then hang around and can provide more defense against herbivorous insects, so this may be happening too. To defend against vertebrate herbivores, the leaves are also coated in really juicy, chemical laden trichomes that probably taste real nasty. It takes a lot to survive in Death Valley, and Anulocaulis annulatus has what it takes! 

#Anulocaulisannulatus #Anulocaulis #valleyringstem #ringstem #nyctaginaceae #botany #botanizing #stickyplants #ecology #wildflowers #deathvalley #californianativeplants

Oenothera primiveris, the yellow desert evening primrose! Not a great common name, because there are dozens of yellow desert evening primrose species, but this is one of the best that I’ve seen! This thing is just pancaked to the ground, with the huge yellow flowers rising up from the center. The flowers are visited by bees and large moths which pick up pollen and then fly it off to the next plant. This species has an adaptation to promote outcrossing (not pollinating itself) by having its four-lobed stigma stuck out far away from its anthers (see photo 4). This lessens the chance that pollen from its own anthers will fertilize the same flower. Many other plants exhibit this spatial and sometimes temporal separation of male and female reproductive parts as it can help keep populations genetically variable. This lessens the chance that a single event will wipe out all individuals in a population by something like a disease or insect pest. Some plants will likely be able to resist these factors better than others, allowing some to survive and reproduce. Also fun fact, next time you see a big Oenothera in flower, give it a sniff, many species smell like Froot Loops cereal.

Erythranthe geniculata! This monkeyflower is one of those plants that seems to have a really specific niche, in this case this plant is usually found growing from cracks in granitic boulders in the Sierra Nevada foothills. I’ve never seen it anywhere else than this very specific habitat. The seeds of this plant (and most monkeyflowers) are like dust, and apparently have no problem dispersing from boulder to distant boulder, because pretty much every boulder large enough to have cracks in it were colonized by this species! Plants that have adapted to living in rock crevices are called chasmophytes, and there are many benefits to this way of life, such as avoiding herbivores if the plant is growing high enough up to be out of reach, growing above plants on the ground so more access to light and far less competition for nutrients and by being on a boulder or cliff, when it rains the water runs down the side and seeps in cracks and crevices, concentrating the amount of water, especially if the cracks go deep. The main drawback being that the plant’s seeds need to find their way into another rock crevice to survive, and that’s no easy task. For a plant like Erythranthe geniculata, seeds falling onto the ground is a death sentence because they will not be able to compete with the more aggressive and taller plants. Pretty cool plant with a cool way of life.

Diplacus douglasii, purple mouse ears! This monkeyflower is one of the most charismatic of them all, and can’t really be confused with any other species. Although widespread in foothills surrounding the Central Valley, I don’t see this plant very often at all, and when I have, most of the time it has been growing in moist areas of serpentine barrens. Its tolerance of this harsh soil chemistry allows it to grow with less competition, which is important for a plant like this which typically only grows a few centimeters tall. The flowers are quite large compared to the size of the rest of the plant and it has an extremely long corolla tube for a monkeyflower, which makes it seem like a long tongued insect is probably the pollinator. It also has an interesting breeding system where it can switch from producing the showy, open insect pollinated flowers to producing closed (cleistogamous) flowers that self pollinate. This switch is typically triggered by longer day length as spring progresses. It can be a good strategy that allows an individual to reproduce even if there are no pollinators out or if there are no other plants to cross pollinate with. Very cool. How could you not love this little plant?!

No photo can show how massive sequoias really are. They’re so unbelievably huge. Over the weekend I went to walk in a grove of them with still about 4 feet of snow on the ground and it was gorgeous. I had the place to myself for about 20 minutes before other people showed up and it was really awe-inspiring. Sequoias are thought to be the most massive trees on earth, though some coast redwoods are thought to have been larger historically and some yet to be found could be larger. They live about 2000-3000 years and are unusual for their trunks remaining wide and stout up most the the length of the trunk. They grow to over 300 feet tall, not the tallest species in the world, but the most impressive thing is walking among the trunks that are 15 and 20 feet across. It is really otherworldly feeling. Everyone must at some point go and walk in a grove of this rare plant, it will change the way you look at trees forever. I also think it’s a powerful testament to how disgustingly wrong it is that old growth forests are still being logged on the earth. Old growth logging robs all of humanity of wonderment and nature of vital ecosystems that can’t be restored for several thousand years. It was wild to see ancient old growth Eucalyptus forests still being logged right now in Tasmania a few months ago. The only reason we still have our giant sequoia groves is because the wood from large trees is brittle and fibrous and the giant trees shatter when felled making recoverable marketable wood not worth the cost of cutting, sawing and transporting it. What was recovered was mostly turned into shingles, fence posts and matchsticks. The loss of such majestic forests to such mundane objects was so despicable even to the settlers in California that laws were passed to protect many of the groves in the late 1800s. Many of the giant stumps and felled trees still lay on the forest floor in the Sierra Nevada, and will for several hundred more years before decaying if they’re not burned in a forest fire. No more old growth logging.

Castilleja exserta, purple owl's clover! This paintbrush is one of California’s most stunning spring annuals wildflowers in the foothills and grasslands. It is a hemiparasite that taps into the roots of nearby plants to steal nutrients, but it still photosynthesizes as well. Most of the purple color is not from the petals, but showy bracts, modified leaves that surround the smaller flowers. It is also a host plant for the Bay checkerspot (Euphydryas editha bayensis), a rare butterfly. Lots to love about this showy plant!

Amsinckia furcata, the forked fiddleneck! This is by far my favorite Amsinckia and one of my all time favorite plants. It is so ridiculously showy not just for an Amsinckia, but for any plant! It is rare (CRPR 4.2) and has a very narrow geographic range, where it grows only from vertic clay soils in the southern coast ranges. Its enormous flowers are also heterostylous, meaning that individual plants either have flowers that have exserted stigmas, this form is called a pin (see photo 1) or flowers with exserted stamens, called thrum (see photo 2). Both forms have male and female parts, but they’re opposites of each other when it comes to what is exserted from the flowers. This promotes outcrossing by minimizing self-fertilization. On the harsh, gypsum rich clay soils, this plant can form extensive stands, painting the hills brilliant orange, and when there are monocultures, mutants stick out! I found a nice scattering of bright yellow flowered morphs in one section of a large stand, showing that this is a genetic mutation that has been passed on to a few plants over the years (see photo 10). I am obsessed with Amsinckias, and this is the best of them all. So damn cool.

Caulanthus inflatus, desert candle… one of the most spectacular native Brassicaceae California has to offer. This large showy annual wildflower is found in the Mojave desert and also in arid regions of the coast ranges of California, where in good rain years, like this year, it can light up steep hillsides like no other species. Its conspicuous, bright yellow, inflated stems are a beacon to pollinators which can spot them at a distance and then visit the small frilly flowers. This species, like some other Caulanthus and Streptanthus have sterile flowers at the top of the stem that are a deep maroon color to make the plant even more noticeable. This is one of those plants that makes me cackle with joy every time I see it! It is so ridiculously showy and unique, and not all that common either! So seeing hillsides this densely packed is a huge treat!!

Papaver heterophyllum, the wind poppy! This is one of the two species in the genus Papaver, the true poppies, native to California, the other being Papaver californicum. The two species are extremely similar looking, but can be distinguished when flowering by having a look at their ovary. Papaver heterophyllum has a fuzzy ball-like stigma on the end of a style where Papaver californicum has no style at all, but with the stigma right on the top of the ovary. Both species are fire followers, with germination usually being triggered by smoke and other chemicals made during a wildfire, but individuals can pop up here and there in the years between fires, as was the case here. Pretty neat and uncommon poppy!

Blainville's Horned Lizard! This cute little lizard is the coast range counterpart to the horned lizards you usually see in the deserts. They’re pretty slow moving and often remain still to blend in with their habitat hoping to be overlooked, but when threatened they have a really weird defensive mechanism where they can shoot a stream of blood out of their eyes at predators! This is apparently offensive enough to coyotes and foxes that it will frighten them off. Being so spiny also makes them a difficult item to eat, though some snakes can still swallow them whole. Probably doesn’t feel too good though. Their main prey is harvester ants, but they will also eat other small insects. It is a protected species in many areas because its range has been highly fragmented by development, invasive ants are replacing the native species it prefers and by exploitation from collectors selling them to the pet trade. Cute little guys deserve better from us.

Erythranthe norrisii, the Kaweah monkeyflower!! This is a very rare (CRPR 1B.3) monkeyflower that has been on my radar for a few years now and yesterday the timing was just right for me to go find it! It is rare due to its very specific and uncommon habitat of marble cliffs in the southern Sierra foothills. The cliff I went to see had a little bit of talus at the bottom, which is where I stepped about 5 feet from a large northern pacific rattlesnake! These are pretty calm snakes though so she just held still and only rattled a little bit when I moved away from her. I always love seeing rattlers! Anyway, I was able to see this plant from the bottom of the cliffs because the flowers are HUGE for a monkeyflower. Way bigger than I had imagined for this species! I thought they’d be similar to Erythranthe geniculata, a related monkeyflower that grows in granite rock crevices in the Sierra foothills, but no, they are big and showy as hell. This species also has pretty unique coloration, with the red splotches at the base of the corolla lobes and whitish patches at the base of the lower two lobes. Really unique plant growing in an extremely rare rock substrate! I was geeking out hard looking at this thing!

Diplacus pictus, the calico monkeyflower! One of the most unique of the 200 or so species of monkeyflowers out there! With flowers that look like some kind of sci-fi portal! This rare plant (CRPR 1B.2) grows almost exclusively at the base of granite boulders in open grassland or oak woodland in the disturbed, coarse sandy soil where ground squirrels have dug burrows among the rocks, often at the edge of the cover of Ribes quercetorum which typically grow in this exact habitat as well. I’ve never seen it growing as densely as it was in the one spot, in typical habitat, apparently unappetizing to the numerous rabbits, cows and ground squirrels I saw in the area. A truly spectacular plant to behold in the wild!

Calochortus amoenus, the purple fairy lantern! This beautiful and unmistakable plant grows in the southern Sierra foothills in grassland often in the shade among oaks. It is one of the few species of Calochortus which have a nodding “fairy lantern” inflorescence along with Calochortus albus, Calochortus amabilis and the rare species Calochortus pulchellus and Calochortus raichei. All of these species tend to grow in similar partly shady woodland/ grassland habitat, so there must be some benefit to having a nodding inflorescence here. The plant reproductive parts are more sheltered from rain, while still being showy, so that’s the main benefit I can think of! In any case, it is a beautiful little lily.

Achyrachaena mollis, soft blow-wives! This common annual aster is so cute and distinctive it deserves a post! It is a monotypic member of the tarweed tribe (Madieae). It is distinctive for its huge pappus scales and the small yellow ray flowers that turn reddish brown as the seed head starts to mature. These contrast with the developing pappus scales, giving the seed head a striped appearance just before it poofs out into its scaly dandelion-like seed head. The common name blow wives is super weird and I can’t find how it got that name, but it is funny to me. Some of y’all probably know!

Calochortus flexuosus, the winding mariposa lily! This beautiful mariposa lily is found throughout much of the Mojave desert and gets its scientific and common names from the winding, almost vine like habit of the stems. In the open, as it is here, it just kinda lays on the ground, but when growing in or near shrubs, it’ll wind its way up through them, using them for support and flower out the top of them! Beautiful little desert lily!

Diplacus mohavensis, the black hole monkeyflower! This is one of the most incredible little wildflowers found in the deserts of California. It has such an interesting flower, similar to that of Diplacus pictus, to which it is only distantly related in the phylogenetic tree of Diplacus. The black hole flower type is so freaking cool the way the corolla really does appear black, and the veins of the flower radiate away from the center in an electrical pattern. I’d love to know what pollinates it! It is also one of the most challenging monkeyflowers to find. It grows in a very non-specific habitat of banks above rocky washes. This niche is open everywhere throughout the deserts of western North America, and yet it only grows in a small geographic area in the Mojave. Then you actually have to spot the thing! They stand just a few centimeters tall among all the other annuals and rocks that they blend in with. Not to mention that they only even come up in good rain years! I was geeking out and shouting to myself out in the desert at sunset when I finally got to see these for the first time. Really special little plants.

Vesper bulbosus, the bulbous springparsley! I’m obsessed with this new to me plant. It is like a beefier version of Vesper purpurascens, which is common in the Great Basin. This species grows in the most barren clay flats that look devoid of life from a distance, but when you get up close, it is covered in this species and other Cymopterus, geophytes and salt and alkaline adapted plant species. I was in this same area 10 months ago and there was no sign of any of these species as it was pretty dry in the area, so to see it so alive is wonderful. Many of you may know that Apiaceae is one of my favorite plant families, especially the Perennial Endemic North American (PENA) clade of Apiaceae. This includes all the Lomatium, Cymopterus, Tauschia, Aletes, Vesper and the smaller lesser known genera like Musineon, Oreonana, Podistera and many others. It a is very diverse, species rich clade and most of them are found only in western North America. Many of them also happen to be among the first plants to bloom in the spring in the intermountain west, so I’m having a great time tracking down species out here in Utah!

Sound up 🔊 to hear a huge coachwhip zip across the rocky ground! The scales sliding across the ground sounds like a freaking bicycle! Coachwhips (Masticophis flagellum) are among the fastest snakes in the US and often flee from people so fast that all you see is a blur moving into the bushes or into the distance! This one actually let us get close for a moment, then it was off to find cover! These beautiful reddish snakes have good eyesight and hunt in the heat of the day, where they catch and eat lizards, rodents and birds. They’re not venomous and are harmless to people, which they are keen to avoid. I’ve just never heard a snake move before! Really neat!

Primula specuicola, the cave-dwelling primrose! This is one of those remarkable plants that leaves you awestruck. It has such a specific niche that is hard to imagine how seeds get from one island of suitable habitat to the next! That habitat is hanging gardens and seeps in sandstone caves! A hanging garden is formed where water seeps out of a cliff face and plants start to grow on the steep face. As organic matter builds up, more plants can grow there. Soon you have a random looking patch of lush vegetation on a cliff or steep slope. Then this species also grows in caves where water seeps out of the rock, but where there is still enough light to photosynthesize. Because they are very shade tolerant, there is little competition with other species except Aquilegia micrantha, a hanging garden/ cave dwelling columbine. Really cool to catch this early blooming species in flower! 

#Primulaspecuicola #Primula #primulaceae #caveprimrose #cavedwellingprimrose #intermountainflora #botany #botanizing #coolplants #flora #flowersofinstagram #coloradoplateau #floraofutah #utahnativeplants

Enceliopsis nutans, the nodding sunray! This awesome aster grows in heavy clay soils from around the San Rafael Swell in Utah east to Grand Junction in Colorado. It is so unlike just about every other aster in the region, and it’s morphology is so confusing that it was unknown whether it belonged to the genus Encelia or Enceliopsis until phylogenetic analysis done in 2007 finally showed it indeed belongs in Enceliopsis. Just looking at the plant, it sure seems to resemble other Enceliopsis to me, the biggest clues being it is a perennial herb, instead of a shrub like most Encelia and the scapose inflorescences (leafless flowering stalks), that are a defining characteristic of Enceliopsis. Other weird things about it are its flat to the ground leaves, discoid flowers (unique in Enceliopsis, and its geophyte lifestyle, where it dies back below ground after flowering, waiting for rain and snow to awake it next spring. Really happy to finally see this plant in flower! It’s a weird one!

#Enceliopsisnutans #enceliopsis #asteraceae #discoidaster #aster #botany #botanizing #floraofutah #intermountainflora #coloradoplateau #Encelianutans #Encelia #wildflowers

Eremocrinum albomarginatum, the lonely lily! This uncommon plant is endemic to the Colorado Plateau in Utah and Arizona, where it grows in sandy flats and dunes. It is monotypic, the only species in its genus. I spent half a day searching for this plant at a couple known locations, but all the individuals I found were still very early, not near flowering. Then on my way back from Colorado, I hopped out to stretch my legs and walk around a bit in eastern Utah and wouldn’t you know it, I found a bunch of them blooming right on the side of the road along with a bunch of other cool plants like the Enceliopsis nutans in the previous post! This awesome and obscure species is related to the more well known desert lily, Hesperocallis undulata, which it certainly resembles other than being much, much smaller. Although both species have lily in the common name, neither are lilies at all, but are actually members of the asparagus family, Asparagaceae! Pretty cute little serendipitous find!

Cymopterus coulteri, the twoleaf springparsley! This rare plant is endemic to central Utah where it grows in clay and gypsum soils derived from the Arapien Shale. Like many edaphic endemics, it has a small geographic range. It is similar to a few other Great Basin species of Cymopterus like Cymopterus corrugatus, Cymopterus ripleyi and Cymopterus globosus, which grow more or less flat to the ground in level areas, but who’s ranges are farther west and typically grow in deep sandy soil. I love the symmetrical look to this cool Apiaceae!

Cylindropuntia wolfi, Wolf’s cholla! This rare (CRPR 4.3) cholla has a small geographic range, like many other Cylindropuntia, and is only found in southeastern San Diego County and bordering Imperial County and just barely across the border into Mexico. Many Cylindropuntia look the same at a glance, and I’m guilty of completely ignoring them most of the time, but seeing this is one of our target species for the week we hit up a known location for it and it is actually a really beautiful plant! Ipomopsis tenuifolia, the slenderleaf skyrocket! This ridiculously cool red Ipomopsis is unlike any other in the states! It’s a perennial with red, bilaterally symmetrical flowers. This species is clearly adapted to hummingbird pollination (almost all bright red flowers with long tubes in the Americas are hummingbird pollinated), and wouldn’t you know it @sheryl_creer found a hummingbird on its nest just a few dozen feet from this plant! Why not live by the store? One of the coolest things about botanizing along the Mexican border is seeing plants whose geographic range just barely makes it into the United States, and this species makes it just a few miles over the border! Because it can only be found in the US in a tiny area, it is listed as rare here (CRPR 2B.3) though it is much more widespread to the south in Mexico. Of course national borders are just imaginary lines made up by people, and have no real meaning in the natural world. Southern San Diego County and northern Baja California are ecologically the same on either side of the border, and so share the same flora and fauna. We were really excited to see this rare little gem!

Velella velella, the by-the-wind sailor. Though they look like a kind of jellyfish, these cool little animals are hydrozoans, related to Hydras and Portuguese man o' war. They have a similar ecology to jellyfish, where they capture small planktonic prey with venomous tentacles which are pretty harmless to people. Interestingly though, what looks like a single animal is actually a colony of individual polyps working together to keep the colony alive. Some form gas bladders to keep the colony afloat, some form the sail and many others are specialized for feeding. These polyps also reproduce sexually by budding off medusae, little free swimming jellyfish which release sperm and eggs. Fertilized eggs then begin developing into another by the wind sailor colony. The sails are made from a chitin skeleton, which allow the animal to sail across the surface of the ocean. Because it is at the mercy of the winds, they are often blown ashore in huge numbers as this one was here. Once on shore, they die and dry up, leaving only the chitin skeleton behind, which you can find on many beaches along the Pacific Ocean. Cool little animals!

Malacothrix floccifera, the woolly desert dandelion! This species usually occurs as scattered individuals in chaparral, forests, and other openings, but in some places it can from vast fields of pale yellow as it was here in the coast ranges! Malacothrix is a member of the aster subfamily Cichorieae, the chicory tribe, which includes familiar plants like chicory, lettuce and dandelions. All members of Cichorieae have milky sap, as you have probably noticed if you’ve ever picked a dandelion or harvested fresh lettuce. Another cool synapomorphy (shared trait) of the tribe is that almost all species, with very few exceptions, have flowering heads containing only ligulate flowers, each with five teeth at the tip! Makes it pretty easy to identify any aster you find to this subfamily!

Thelypodiopsis elegans, the Westwater tumblemustard! This is a really cool and uncommon native mustard that grows in eastern Utah and western Colorado. It is certainly one of the showiest native Brassicaceae in the region along with Stanleya, which this plant is a close relative of. Brassicaeae is often written off as a boring family because there are so many cosmopolitan weeds that usually come to mind, or even frustration with native genera, eg. Boechera, which are notoriously hard to identify to species, but western North America is loaded with native mustard diversity, some common, some extremely rare, and all are with a close look and appreciation!
