You know I love my side by sides! Here is a great illustration of the difference between the very common variety of narrow leaved miners lettuce, Claytonia parviflora ssp. parviflora, on the left and the rare (CRPR 4.2) variety, Claytonia parviflora ssp. grandiflora, on the right. It’s one of those things where it is easy to tell when they grow together, but can be difficult when seeing only one subspecies in an area. The most obvious difference is the much larger flower size of ssp. grandiflora, meant to be a bigger signal to pollinators, because this taxa is adapted to cross pollination. Which is where the real difference comes into play. Subspecies parviflora is self pollinating, where it’s anthers and stigma mature at the same time and are in close proximity (see photo 2). Subspecies grandiflora is protoandrous, meaning the anthers mature first and spread out away from the stigma, to avoid self pollinating (see photo 3 where the anthers are mature but the stigma is just developing). Then once the anthers have shed their pollen, the three lobed stigma matures with the anthers spread far away from it (photo 4). It is a really clever way to promote outcrossing to ensure its offspring have more diverse genes than varieties that self pollinate! Photos 5-10 are all of subspecies grandiflora. Some plants listed as rare can be extremely abundant locally, but have limited geographic ranges, such is case here where I saw entire mountainsides covered in Claytonia parviflora ssp. grandiflora which is thriving in a recent burn in Sequoia National Park! In photo 10 you can see huge white swaths of this plant covering acres along with Malacothamnus fremontii. Rare plants by the millions! 

I also love that the scientific name translates to the large flowered small flowered Claytonia lololol.

Finally got to see Clarkia breweri, fairy fans, in flower for the first time yesterday! I’ve seen this plant in bud half a dozen times, but they sure take their time opening. Clarkia breweri grows on rocky slopes and talus, usually on serpentine or other ultramafic rocks in the coast ranges of California. 

This species and the closely related Clarkia concinna are distinctive as being the only Clarkias that only have 4 stamens, all the other species have 8, but that is more of an evolutionary curiosity than a tool for identifying these species, as they’re so distinctive, you wouldn’t confuse them for any other Clarkias. As with other large California genera, it’s always nice to see a new to me species, to get get a more complete understanding of their diversity and ecology. Sweeeet.

Lewisia rediviva, bitterroot! This charismatic species is found all over western North America from California north to southern Canada and east to  Montana (where the Bitterroot Mountains get their name) and down along the Rocky Mountains. It grows in thin rocky soils and is tolerant of serpentine and other ultramafic soil. It has succulent leaves that emerge early in spring and give way to big white to pink flowers that appear huge for the size of the plant. Here on mount Diablo it was especially spectacular growing on an otherwise nearly barren rock ridge! In a few weeks the flowers will set seed and the plant will disappear underground to wait out the heat of the summer as thick root until rains return next year. Who doesn’t love bitterroot?!

Chia seeds! Salvia columbariae is a common annual plant in the desert and other dry areas of California and is a source of chia seeds! It isn’t the same species that is cultivated though, that is Salvia hispanica, but the seeds can be used the same! The flavor is pretty much identical, though Salvia columbariae we’re a little crunchier. Also shown here is Salvia carduacea, another annual Salvia that produces similar, larger seeds. Salvia is a member of the mint family, Lamiaceae and is also the same genus that the culinary herb sage is in, as well as dozens of showy cultivated species. So yea, your chia seeds are in the mint family!

Look at how cute this bee is! It was feverishly collecting the brilliant maroon pollen of the very rare (CRPR 1B.2)  Calochortus excavatus. It seemed to collect a bunch of pollen, then sip nectar from the nectaries of the flower, and then mix it together on its leg pouches! This sugar and protein rich mixture will then be deposited in an underground burrow and an egg laid on it. This will be all the food its young will need to survive! I haven’t any idea what species of bee this is, so if anyone does, I’d love to know. I have a feeling it is probably a pretty rare bee if it is foraging from a rare plant in a rare alkaline spring ecosystem!

Asclepias eastwoodiana, Eastwood's Milkweed! This rare little milkweed is endemic to the Great Basin of Nevada, where it is found sporadically. Here it was growing on a silty mound adjacent to an ashy deposit covered in edaphic endemics like Lepidium nanum, Erigeron compactus, Artemisia pygmaea, Astragalus toanus, and many others! I’ve seen this species once before in the Quinn Canyon Range, but the individuals there were pretty sad looking. These from today are in their prime from all the rain and snow! Another thing that struck me was its fragrance! You could smell it from 5 feet away! Like a super sweet and fruity smell. This and the nectar that you can see oozing from the flowers in photo 5 make this an attractive pollinator plant! Really stoked on how lush and floriferous the Great Basin is right now!

Cymopterus basalticus, the basalt springparsley! This uncommon plant is only found in the Great Basin of eastern Nevada and western Utah, where it grows, despite its name, on rocky limestone soil as well other substrates. To me it looks very similar to Cymopterus gilmanii of the Death Valley region, but growing in a much colder, pinyon/ juniper habitat. Also, its fruit is really distinct with thick corky wings. This is one I’ve been wanting to see for a few years, so it has been nice to see abundantly in a few different places out here!

Trifolium friscanum, the Frisco clover! This is a rare clover that is only known from the higher ridges and slopes of a few mountain ranges in western Utah. A big group of us hiked up to the ridge of the Tunnel Springs Range to see this plant and others during the first annual Intermountain Botanical Foray! Was a great way to nerd out hard with a bunch of other cool western plant enjoyers. Looking forward to some more forays in the future!

Oxytropis oreophila var. juniperina! This cool taxa has no common name, and confused me pretty good! I thought I had found some gnarly Astragalus, but it turned out to be this obscure variety of the mountain oxytrope that grows at lower elevations on the bottom of basins in Nevada. It grew with a whole cast of other interesting ashy knoll loving species, many of which have the alpine cushion growth habit as this plant does, despite being on the bottom of the valley floor. I’ll have to do a post on these cool plants soon!

Micropuntia pulchella, the sagebrush cholla! This is a mind blowing little cactus! It is unlike any others in the US, due to its super cool geophytic habit. It is deciduous, shedding all above ground vegetation during dry periods and persisting as an underground tuber until rain and snow returns! During good precipitation years like this, it’ll bloom prolifically from its small little cholla branches. But in very dry years it may not emerge at all, or just send up a few vegetative shoots. See photo 5 for a look at this small cholla’s underground tuber! This plant was collected and pressed as a voucher for the flora of the Desert Experimental Range in Utah during the Intermountain Botanical Foray over the weekend! Such a cool way to see this amazing cactus!

Johanneshowellia crateriorum, the Lunar Crater buckwheat! This awesome and unique little buckwheat is endemic to the Lunar Crater region of Nevada, where it grows in pumice and cinder flats. It is one of two species in the genus Johanneshowellia, the other being Johanneshowellia puberula (see photo 9). Both are endemic to the Great Basin and differ from the genus Eriogonum by not having their involucral bracts fused together into a tube. This morphological trait probably arose within the genus Eriogonum and these plants are likely nested within that genus. This was my third time attempting to see this plant. I searched the area in 2021 and 2022 and there was no sign of it. It sure seems to be dependent on heavy precip years to emerge, because this year there were thousands! This was a major target plant for me this year so I’m stoked to have caught it in peak flower!

Physocarpus alternans, Nevada ninebark! This uncommon desert Rosaceae grows from shady parts of steep limestone cliffs throughout Nevada, parts of Utah and the carbonate desert mountains of California. Surprisingly, this was the first inat record of this species actually in Nevada! This is likely due to this plant’s inaccessible habitat preferences rather than it being very rare, so it is underreported. I had never seen it blooming until last week, and it is a seriously beautiful little shrub! These plants were very compact and only a foot or so tall, hugging the limestone. The Great Basin is incredibly lush right now, and continuing to get lots of rain from thunderstorms, so just about anything that can bloom is blooming! So cool!

The heavy thunderstorms the last couple days in the Owens Valley awoke hundreds of Great Basin spadefoot toads (Spea intermontana) from their slumber deep underground! This desert adapted toad spends most of its life buried underground where they wait out the cold and then the extreme heat and dry of their desert habitat, until heavy rains trigger an emergence, where many toads come out and find large puddles to sing, mate and lay eggs in! As it heats up, the toads burrow back into the soil using the hard, keratinized “spades” found on each of their back legs (see photos 3 and 4). This is obviously where they get their name from! Their eggs hatch in a couple days and tadpoles develop rapidly, with metamorphosis taking 1-2 months. They have to grow and develop quickly, because large puddles and pools don’t last very long out in the desert. Lucky for the spadefoots here in the Owens Valley it is looking like a great year for them, with a previous round of hundreds of tadpoles already nearly full size and growing back legs were seen in a very large pool of water. So many tadpoles were in there that we even saw some albino ones that seem to be making it out just fine! This was my first time seeing these cute little toads, and seeing so many hopping around in the rain was super cool!

Xylorhiza tortifolia, the Mojave-aster! This common plant is having a banger year, with all the precip we’ve had they’re loaded with big purple flowers! This is one of those genera with one really common and widespread species (this one) and then a bunch of really rare narrowly endemic species spread across western North America! But just because this one is common doesn’t mean it isn’t a ridiculously beautiful plant. Definitely belongs in desert native plant gardens in California!

Penstemon palmeri! This is a huge and pretty common penstemon in parts of the deserts of California and Nevada. They grow about 4-5 feet tall and have delicious candy smelling flowers. Penstemom’s common name is beardtongue, and it gets this from the staminode (a sterile stamen) that is very hairy and exserted from the corolla in some species of this genus such as this one. Spectacular!

How about the colors on this grasshopper?! It’s Poecilotettix sanguineus, the red-lined grasshopper! I’ve been seeing these little gems mostly hiding in the Tetradymia stenolepis around here, but I’ve also seen them in and eating Ambrosia salsola. They’re not nearly as abundant as many of the other grasshoppers around here, and that seems to make seeing these that more special. With the massive amount of plant biomass this year, insects are booming right now in the Owens Valley. Today I was lazy and just hung around one spot peering into bushes and spotting all kinds of different insects going about their lives. As many of you may know, insects were my first passion, and were the roundabout way I became interested in native plants. I collected seeds from all the local plants I’d see on Boy Scout trips and then plant them at home in a big native plant garden with the specific intention of attracting cool insects. In the process I became obsessed with the plants themselves! But I never lost my love for the arthropods! Especially cicadas! The best of the insects. Grasshoppers are pretty cool too though 🤓.

Welcome to a new era of botanizing… the last year or so I’ve been having heart arrhythmia issues that have made it difficult for me to do strenuous hiking, which has really bummed me out, so I’ve mostly just been doing roadside botany or hikes that aren’t as crazy as I used to typically do, so I got to thinking, fantasizing really, about being able to investigate my favorite rare plant habitats, steep rocky areas and cliffs, via drone. So I did a bunch of research and finally pulled the trigger and holy shit… we are living in a sci-fi world right now. It’s been humanity’s dream to fly for eons, and sure you can get on a jet and fly through the air and be transported somewhere else, but you have no control of where to go except for your predetermined destination. Of course the drone can’t physically transport me, but it can transport my sense of sight in real-time, casting my eyes miles away, soaring through the air towards cliffs I’ve wanted to inspect for years and then reaching them within minutes! I’ve been scream laughing every time I’ve flown it so far in disbelief about how freely I can float from one outcrop to the next, snapping photos of utterly unreachable plants all the while. Yesterday I flew over to some tantalizing limestone cliffs and found a new occurrence of Hecastocleis shockleyi in a few minutes, which you can see in the last clip in the video! Proof of concept that a consumer drone is very capable of rare plant reconnaissance! There are some pretty strict rules of where drones can be flown of course, so a lot of places are off limits like National Parks, wilderness areas, near airports, etc. and the software in the drone I have won’t even allow it to take off or fly into  designated no fly zones like these. Then you also need to not be a jerk with it, like not flying it near people (rarely anyone within miles of where I am botanizing in the deserts), or where birds are nesting or flying. I’m so stoked to cruise around hunting for these out of reach species!

Hecastocleis shockleyi! This rare (CRPR 3) shrub is entirely unique in the world. It is the only member of its entire subfamily, Hecastocleidoideae, in Asteraceae. Out on a long lonesome evolutionary branch for millions of years, and it finds itself growing on rocky slopes of outcrops in eastern California and western Nevada. It is unusual in having only one flower per involucre. That is, each flower has its own set of phyllaries around it (see photo 3), rather than a daisy looking flower with dozens of florets all in a flower head all sharing one set of phyllaries. The flowers of Hecastocleis do grow in clusters, a pseudocapitulum, but they are all independent from each other. They are also surrounded by spiny, lighter colored bracts, which may help as an attractant and help with defense. This species is spiny as all hell. With the older leaves drying into sharp, serrated spines. So it is well adapted to its high desert habitat, but is apparently not good at dispersing or setting much viable seed, as it is almost always growing in isolated little pockets, though in these pockets it can be locally abundant! It is probably also picky with the soil chemistry it likes. In any case, it has been here for many millions of years, hanging on, so hopefully it’ll be around a long time from now too! It’s a really cool plant to sit and stare at! 

#Hecastocleisshockleyi #Hecastocleis #Hecastocleideae #Hecastocleidoideae #asteraceae #compositae #botany #botanizing #rareplants #californianativeplants #rareplant #botany #botanizing

Echinocereus engelmannii fruit! I see this common cactus in flower every year all over the southwestern US and somehow this is the first time I’ve ever seen fruit on it! I had to investigate and see how one tasted, so I plucked off a fruit, brushed off the spines and it split so easily. It looks just like dragonfruit, which isn’t too surprising because dragonfruit is from a cactus too! I ate I nice big bite of the white fruit and holy hell. It is absolutely delicious! Definitely the best tasting cactus fruit I’ve had! It tastes a lot like dragonfruit, but much sweeter, with a better flavor too, but no hint of bitterness as with some other cacti! Most of the Echinocereus fruits that we saw were already ripped open by animals that no doubt relish them! @sheryl_creer  made a good point about never seeing the ripe fruit, because the animals probably devour them the moment they become ripe!

It has been a great year for the genus Nemacladus! These are members of Campanulaceae, the bellflower family, that are adapted to arid habitats, especially deserts, and tend to grow in sandy or fine gravelly soils. They are also minuscule, usually invisible at a glance and often only spotted when bending down to inspect some other belly plants! Many of these species are uncommon, with quite a few being described in the last few years. Though, they are likely much more widespread than is currently known due to their fleeting existence and difficult to spot. Their known ranges are regularly expanded with new populations being identified. For instance, the Nemacladus morefieldii in photo 4 was a range extension of 125 miles deep into Nevada, and the “Nemacladus sigmoideus” in photo 7 is a range extension of about 185 miles and this extremely disjunct population may actually represent a distinct, undescribed species in eastern Nevada. 

1. Nemacladus rubescens
2. Nemacladus matsonii
3. Nemacladus orientalis
4. Nemacladus morefieldii
5. Nemacladus rigidus
6. Nemacladus sigmoideus
7. “Nemacladus sigmoideus” highly disjunct and morphologically distinct. May be an undescribed taxon. 
8. Nemacladus californicus

Here’s that Nemacladus taxon that may just be a morphologically weird, highly disjunct Nemacladus sigmoideus, or an undescribed taxon in eastern Nevada. According to a Nemacladus expert, the large disjunction, yellow tipped corolla lobes and maroon filament tube and anthers make this population different from the main populations in California. Even, cooler, I managed to snap a photo this extremely small flower’s even smaller pollinator!! It is a tiny species of wasp, that I’m betting some of you may know the family. The flower itself is maybe 2 or 3 mm, so the wasp is probably around a mm in length! Even the tiniest flowers out there have pollinators!

Clarkia pulchella, large-flower clarkia! Just look at this ridiculous thing! This species is native to the mountains of Idaho, Montana and eastern Oregon and Washington! It is clearly closely related to Clarkia concinna not just by the shape of the petals, but by the fact that it only has 4 stamens, where most other Clarkia have 8. What is really weird and stands out even at a distance is the big, pure white stigma! Clarkia concinna has nothing like that! Was really cool to finally see this plant in prime flower!

A beautiful desert spring system in an extremely remote part of Nevada for the solstice… some of the springs are hot springs, hot tub temperature water, while others were much milder. Isolated desert spring systems like this are essentially always home to very rare plant and animal species, and this was the case here! Here is what I found!

Photo 1: The hot spring system!

Photos 2-3: Epipactis gigantea, a wetland orchid that has a knack for showing up at isolated desert springs.

Photos 4-5: Sphenopholis obtusata, a cool grass that is found all over the eastern US, and then completely randomly at extremely isolated desert springs in the western US. 

Photo 6: Artemisia potentilloides, a cool showy species of alkaline loving sagebrush!

Photos 7-8: Potentilla basaltica, a very rare endemic to this area and an isolated population on the Modoc Plateau.

Photo 9: A new species of Amphipod in the genus Hyalella! I found this little crustacean while digging around the aquatic roots of Berula erecta looking for spring snails after @belly_plants turned me onto them! No snails, but this blue amphipod was all over them! @coreyjlange had told me about how many desert springs have unknown species of amphipods at them, relicts from the ice age, when these spring systems would have been connected to other waterways like streams and lakes. Now isolated for over 12,000 years, many have speciated, as this one likely has into a new, unknown species! How sick!

Corydalis caseana ssp. cusickii, fitweed! This monstrous Corydalis grows about 4-5 feet tall, an absolute behemoth compared to most Corydalis, which are usually tiny forest herbs! It is found along montane streams where it grows rapidly after snowmelt. The vegetation is glaucous and succulent, looking just like other members of the tribe, just scaled up. This crazy thing is a member of Papaveraceae, the poppy family, mind you! It has one of the more bizarre ranges of any western plant (see photo 9), being found in widely scattered populations which have evolved into 5 different subspecies. Trying to hypothesize how ranges like this came about is like candy to the brain. Was this species once much more widespread and these are relictual populations? Does it somehow have a propensity for long distance dispersal events? So curious and wondrous. I love plants like this so much. Uncommon, spectacular, disjunct and thought provoking. 

#Corydaliscaseana #Corydaliscaseanacusickii Corydalis #papaveraceae #fumarioideae #corydaleae #fitweed #botany #botanizing #floraofidaho #wildflowers #montaneflowers #mountains #plants

Veronica missurica, mountain kittentails! This cool little wildflower is found in disjunct populations in Idaho, Montana, eastern Oregon and Washington, and then with two big disjunct populations in the Columbia River Gorge around Cascade Locks, and in the Warner Mountains of California! This genus used to be called Synthyris, but it has been found to be nested within the very variable genus Veronica, and the flowers sure look similar even if the leaves don’t. The reason for this name change is because the linage we called Synthyris is derived from members of the genus Veronica, so to ensure the clade is monophyletic, some morphologically distinct lineages need to be lumped into the large genus Veronica, because the alternative is splitting the genus Veronica into many new genera, of which many have the same morphological and structural characteristics, but would all have different names making identifying them without genetic work or expertise difficult. 

It is analogous to the absorption of the genus Dodecatheon into Primula, from which it is derived. To not include Dodecatheon in Primula would require breaking up the large genus Primula into many smaller genera, even though the species within are morphologically similar. 

Yay systematics!

#Veronicamissuricamissurica #Veronicamissurica #Veronica #Synthyrismissurica #Synthyris #plantaginaceae #floraofidaho #idahonativeplants #botany #botanizing #mountainkittentails #systematics

I was in Utah about a month or so ago and went to visit an incredible pictograph and petroglyph site near a large rock overhang area. The artwork was amazing, but unfortunately a bunch of assholes over the years have carved their initials, shot at and otherwise defaced the rock face as well. But! There was something else here that absolutely intrigued me. I noticed a plant growing in the sandy soil around the bases of the cliffs, Eriocoma hymenoides, ricegrass! Now this is by no means an uncommon grass. It is by far one of the most common and widespread native bunch grasses in drier parts of western North America, from roasting low elevation deserts to alpine peaks. What is intriguing is that the individuals at this cultural site are ENORMOUS. Both in terms of overall clump size, and especially the size of the grains! This fascinated me because this species of grass has been a staple food source for indigenous people from time immemorial. This leads me to think that these plants may be descended from a cultivated form that was intentionally bred and selected for large grain sizes. This is all just me pondering, but it seems like it would make sense, especially given they were found at a culturally important site!

Canbya aurea, the yellow pygmy-poppy! This rare little poppy is the lesser known of the two species in the genus Canbya, the other being Canbya candida, the white pygmy poppy of the Mojave and Southern Sierra Nevada. Canbya aurea is only found in northwestern Nevada and just across the border into Oregon, though I think there is habitat nearby in California that it has the possibility of it existing there. It grows in sandy soil and is having an incredible year. I found it in three different occurrences, two of which had tens of thousands of plants carpeting the ground! Unfortunately I saw them on a stormy cloudy day so the flowers weren’t open, except for a single one on one plant! This is a really cute little thing I’d been wanting to see for years, so it was cool to see them thriving!

Cirsium occidentale var. candidissimum, the snowy thistle! The bright red flowers against white vegetation is so stunning. The flowers are adapted to being pollinated by hummingbirds, and the vegetation is white because the plant is covered in dense cobwebby hairs which help block excess light and keep moisture in. I probably post this species every year or two, because it is just so damn cool. It shatters the stereotype that thistles are all spiny invasive weeds. Though some are notorious invasives, California has 38 taxa of native thistles, many of which are very rare and are in need of conservation. Luckily, Cirsium occidentale var. candidissimum is pretty common in hot, dry areas of Northern California! Always have to stop and look at these up close!

This is one of those very cryptic wildflowers that grows in moist shady areas, often hidden in other vegetation, so spotting its tiny green flowers can be challenging! At a glance it doesn’t look like much, but upon close inspection it’s tiny flowers are spectacular! Like a little green and reddish snowflake!

Cycladenia humilis! This unique member of the milkweed family (Apocynaceae) has no good common name other than Cycladenia. It’s is pretty randomly distributed in the mountains of California, where it’s is uncommon throughout, but can be locally abundant. Strangely, one variety, Cycladenia humilis var. jonesii, is found in eastern Utah and northern Arizona in very different soils and habitats and is quite rare. No matter the location, I typically see it on steep, sandy or gravelly slopes, but then sometimes on lava flows. The leaves of individual plants can be either completely glabrous or densely velvety hairy, with both forms growing side by side (see photo 7 for a hairy form that was with the mostly glabrous population). These used to be considered different varieties, but it seems more likely that it is just a result of two phenotypes within a population, as the plants are otherwise identical. This difference is likely determined by a single gene, as is the case with the related Amsonia tomentosa, which also has glabrous and densely velvety hairy individual plants in the same populations. Cycladenia is a pretty awesome and unique plant worth seeking out and appreciating!

I came upon something incredible in northwestern Nevada a few weeks back! The rare Lupinus uncialis, the inchhigh lupine, growing right next to an obsidian artifact! That’s some pretty damn good luck if you ask me! I’d never seen this species, which really is about an inch tall, and went down to get a good look at the tiny flowers when I noticed the artifact! This species of lupine grows in the area where California, Nevada and Oregon meet and it can be really easily overlooked due to its size and even smaller flowers. I only really noticed it because it was growing with Canbya aurea, my target plant for the day! That’s usually how it goes for me. I’ll select one or a few species I really want to see and I’ll track them down, and in the process end up seeing all kinds of cool plants, insects and other cool things!

Checking out the cones of the world’s largest species of pine, the sugar pine (Pinus lambertiana)! This species hold the records for being the tallest and most massive of all pines, up to 273 feet tall and growing to a diameter of 11.5 feet. It also has the longest cones of any conifer, growing to 2 feet long, though the coulter pine (Pinus coulteri) of Southern California has more massive cones. This species has its huge pine cones characteristically dangling from the very ends of its upper branches, making it utterly distinctive and identifiable from a long way away, so I thought I’d fly up and get a good look at them! You can see the previous year’s cones open and dry, their seeds all released last fall. You can also see the closed, shiny reddish cones that are still developing! Sugar pines, like many conifers, have winged seeds that helicopter down like maple seeds in the fall, being wind dispersed, but the big tasty seeds are so sought after by birds, bears and squirrels, that many are collected and eaten or stashed away before even taking flight! In this frenzied collection though, seeds are spread far and wide by wing or foot, then buried in the soil to be eaten later. But if the critter that stashed them dies or forgets where they are, then the seeds will sprout from the soil in spring! It is such a treat to get to hike around these remote and rugged Southern Cascade forests with these trees scattered in it. This plant is just so awe-inspiring!

Silene occidentalis ssp. longistipitata! This rare (CRPR 1B.2) Silene is distinct from the other subspecies, ssp. occidentalis, by the extremely long calyx tube, up to about 40 mm (see photo 6)! This very long tube and big white flowers that open in the evening and shrivel in the day are clues that this species is pollinated by very long tongued moths, likely hawk moths, which can reach the nectar at the bottom of the calyx. An adaptation that makes this species very attractive only to long-tongued moths which can reach the reward of nectar, and discourages more generalist pollinators from visiting, who may be covered in pollen from different plant species that would not be able to fertilize the flower, and who would also carry away pollen to other unrelated species, effectively wasting it and reducing the chance that the Silene flowers in a population would get properly fertilized and set seed. Sometimes it is an excellent strategy to adapt to attracting a silver bullet pollinator species like a long tongued hawk moth, who will be focused on a single species in an area, taking advantage of a resource other insects can’t reach, moving only the pollen of the Silene around to other Silene flowers. One big drawback of this strategy though, is that if your single (or several) pollinator species goes extinct, you are also doomed. There are always trade offs in biology, but so many ways to exist and reproduce. This is one of those ways!

Lilium pardalinum ssp. shastense, the Shasta lily! This marvelous lily is very common in the region just about anywhere there are wetlands! This is fortunate because it never gets any less spectacular each time I see it! This was the first time I noticed a pollinator on it though, and it’s a big one! It’s a pale swallowtail (Papilio eurymedon), and the big dangly flowers finally make sense. While the swallowtail hangs on and drinks nectar, it’s body is bumping right into the anthers and stigma of the lily! See this in photo 8, and also notice that the base of its wings are all dusted with lily pollen! Makes sense that big flowers would have big pollinators!

Asarum hartwegii, Hartweg’s wild ginger! This plant is pretty common throughout moister areas of montane California, and would make an awesome garden plant in shady places. The leaves are just so showy and intricate! Species in the genus Asarum are often called wild ginger because their rhizomes have a spicy smell similar to ginger, though they are not closely related to culinary ginger at all. Still, people sometimes use it like ginger, though this is not advisable because Asarum contains aristolochic acids, which are carcinogenic and very toxic to the kidneys. People who eat or take dietary supplements containing Asarum have a higher risk of kidney and bladder cancers. This happens due to the metabolites of aristolochic acids forming DNA adducts, where the chemical Aristolactam I chemically binds to strands of DNA and can interfere with its replication, leading to mutations and possible cancer. These DNA adducts are also very stable and can be used as a biomarker, with Aristolactam I adducts being detectable in patients up to 20 years after exposure. This is a valuable reminder that just because something is natural, doesn’t mean it is safe. Cyanide, strychnine, and ricin are all completely natural compounds made by plants!

Lilium parvum, the Sierra tiger lily! This stunning lily grows abundantly along many of the small creeks and streams and other wetlands in the Sierra Nevada Mountains. The specific name “parvum” means small, and sure enough, the flowers of this species are quite small for the genus (see photos 7 and 8). It can be easily distinguished from some similar species that share its range like Lilium pardalinum and Lilium kelleyanum, which both have larger flowers that are pendant. Lilium parvum’s flowers are usually spreading to ascending. Stoked to come across large populations of such a cool plant!

Brasenia schreberi, the watershield! This awesome aquatic plant is rare in California (CRPR 2B.3), being scattered in little populations all over the northern half of the state. Though rare in here, this plant has an enormous geographic range, being found scattered across North America where I’ve seen it now in California, Maine and Florida. In fact, it is found on 6 continents! Pretty much anywhere there is still water in ponds and lakes where there is a thick accumulation of organic matter at the bottom this plant can be randomly found. The coolest thing about it to me is the thick mucilage that coats all underwater surfaces of the plant (see photos 5-7). This is thought to be an anti-herbivory adaptation against snails and other aquatic herbivores. The gel gums up their mouthparts and provides a physical barrier between the plant and attackers. This plant’s flowers are also really cool. It is wind pollinated, and each flower blooms for two days. On the first day it is pistillate (female) with receptive stigmas exserted (see photos 3 and 4). Then on the second day the flower switches to its staminate (male) phase (see photos 1 and 2), and releases all of its pollen onto the breeze! 

It was quite a feat getting to this plant, as it tends to grow in somewhat deeper water. I just waded out into the lake until the water was about 3 feet deep, but the problem wasn’t the water depth, but the muck on the bottom depth! My feet would sink in about a foot with each step and get suctioned into the goop. I had to abandon my flip flops because they got pulled off my feet and I had to spend a few minutes digging them out of the depths. Was super with it though to see such cool aquatic plants! Wetlands are just the best, teeming with plant and animal life!

Nuphar polysepala, the western yellow pond lily! Another awesome aquatic plant! This one is also found deeper water of small ponds, lakes and slow moving streams. Its huge yellow flowers are pollinated by beetles and other flying insects. Speaking of beetles, I noticed a bunch of little leaf beetles all over the lily pads in this population munching away and creating little holes. I was pretty sure that this had to be some kind of specialist beetle because of the unique habitat and sure enough, it is Galerucella nymphaeae, the water lily leaf beetle! Their lives revolve around feeding on lily pads, which frees them from attack by terrestrial predators for the most part, but probably makes them easy picking for wading birds and small frogs. It’s always a trade off in nature, and this lifestyle seems to work just fine, as the beetle is common across much of northern North America wherever pond lilies are found!

Kyhosia bolanderi is a really cool monotypic member of the tarweed tribe (Madieae). It is unusual for tarweeds in that it likes growing in wet meadows and stream sides. It’s just a really neat plant with a somewhat small geographic range! Worth seeking out and admiring!

Insects never cease to amaze me. They were my first passion before plants. Here I thought I found this Parnassius clodius with some kind of fungal infection, but the reality is so much weirder! This is a female Parnassius clodius that has a structure called a sphragis, on its abdomen. It is a mating plug created by male butterflies during copulation. The male excretes a waxy substance that dries to build this hollow structure on the female, making a physical barrier, preventing other males from mating with the female, ensuring she only produces his offspring. A really wild way to ensure your genes continue into the future! If you ever want to see extreme specialization in nature, insects are what you want to study!

Lobelia cardinalis at one of its only Nevada occurrences! Like a little piece of Florida placed in a valley in the Great Basin, this species was growing abundantly along a crystal clear blue geothermally heated creek. For some reason, plants normally found in eastern North America are often found disjunct at hot springs and other geothermal areas in the middle of deserts in Nevada in California. Some other oddball plants that were here were Sphenopholis obtusata and Fimbrystylis, both apparent hot spring lovers as I’ve seen them both frequently in those habitats. Any isolated spring systems geothermal or otherwise, that have been around for tens of thousands of years or more are certain to have interesting assemblages of plant species, often very rare or endemic ones!

Torreya californica is a rare and really cool species of conifer in Taxaceae, the yew family. It is endemic to California and has a super fragmented distribution in the coast ranges and the Cascade and Sierra foothills. The extreme fragmentation of its range suggest it is a relict species that was once more widespread during cooler climate periods, a pattern which Torreya taxifolia, the Florida Torreya shares. That species is now restricted to a tiny glacial refugium in the Florida panhandle and bordering southwest Georgia. 

Torreya californica is an understory specialist, where is can persist for long periods waiting for the canopy to open after a large tree falls and take advantage of the light to start reproducing. I’ve also noticed them growing and bearing cones often on the edges of gravel roads, as this one here was. As a member of the yew family, their cones are highly modified, usually with only one seed per cone that is enveloped in a fleshy aril. In Torreya, the aril envelopes the entire seed, the resulting cone is analogous to a drupe in angiosperms. The very large drupe-like cones are apparently mainly dispersed by rodents, which cache the seeds to be eaten later. If forgotten or the rodents die before they are dug up and eaten, they can sprout into new trees!

Photo 1: A cone in my hand for scale, they’re huge!

Photo 2: The cones take about 18 months to develop, so here you can see the large, nearly mature cones with a few tiny ones that are just starting to develop below.

Photo 3: The megastrobili, the pollen receptive young female cones. 

Photo 4: The microstrobili, the male cones which produce pollen. 

Photos 5-7: The very stiff, sharp needles.

Photo 8: The bark of a medium sized tree.

Photos 9-10: At first I though these might be a rust fungus that I’ve seen on Torrey before, Rogerpetersonia torreyae, but closer inspection seems to reveal them to be a scale insect. Hopefully a native and pretty unique one to be feeding on such a unique tree!

Eriogonum darrovii is a really obscure and rare buckwheat known from a few places in Nevada, Arizona and Utah. It has to be one of the most unique Eriogonum species of them all. It doesn’t look like any other I know of, with large cauline leaves from every node associated with an involucre. The flowers are also highly modified with the outer tepals ciliate at the distal and proximal ends but not in the center. I’d love to know where this species sits in the phylogenetic tree of Eriogonum! I bet it is way out there on a branch!

I visited this spot in eastern Nevada on June 1st and found a few of these plants with just a single flower, so last weekend I stopped by again with @_xylemphloem and we found over a hundred of this plant in perfect flower! We were both so struck by how weird and wonderful it was!

Cirsium arizonicum, the Arizona thistle! This beautiful native thistle is found in the southwestern US and is one of a few species with bright red flowers, that have evolved to be primarily pollinated by hummingbirds! The individuals in this population in the Fortification Range, Nevada were all much smaller than I remember seeing them in Utah, with most flowering plants only about 2 feet tall. It is always important to be reminded that there are dozens of species of native thistles in North America! It’s too easy to think of thistles as nasty, spiny invasive weeds, of which some area, but those usually grow in disturbed areas like farms, cattle stomped wetlands, roadsides and burns. So learn your local native thistles and be sure not to kill them!

One my coolest Carex encounters I’ve had so far was finding Carex limosa cooccurring with its close relative Carex magellanica in the Uinta Mountains in northern Utah yesterday! I wasn’t aware that their ranges overlapped at all, so I was really excited to see them both growing within a foot of each other! They’re members of the sect. Limosae, which contains just 6 species, all of which look fairly similar and share the trait of having dense yellow hairs coating the roots.

In photos 1-4, Carex limosa is on the left and Carex magellanica is on the right. 

These two species are very easy to identify on their own, with dangling inflorescences and bog or other saturated habitats at high elevation. I’ve seen them both on their own before, and thought how extremely similar they looked, but now having them side by side the differences are obvious. Carex limosa has larger perigynia and pistillate scales that don’t or barely surpass the perigynia. Carex magellanica has smaller perigynia that often have a bluish tint (which doesn’t show up well in photos) and has pistillate scales that are much longer than most of the perigynia and are narrow and point at the tip, giving the inflorescence a spiny look. What was also really cool was that they seemed to occupy different microhabitats within the bog! I only saw Carex limosa growing in open, standing water (see photo 5) whereas I only saw Carex magellanica growing from mats of sphagnum moss at the edges of the water, but not actually growing up out of the water like Carex limosa (see photo 6). 

You gotta wonder if the two species can hybridize, as they’re clearly close relatives, and grow right next to each other here. I’ll try to look into that! In any case, I was happy to get my feet wet early in the morning for these two awesome sedges!

Got some good quality time with my favorite mammal, the American pika, in Wyoming a few days ago! They are just the absolute cutest little things. Related to rabbits, they live in high elevation, cold mountain ranges where they collect plant material like this and then dry it on rocks to make hay. They then take this hay to their homes deep in talus, fellfields and other bouldery areas. Because they don’t hibernate, they need to eat all winter long so they need to make as much hay as possible before the snow falls! I want to hold one so badly 🥺.

Throwback to all of the awesome Podocarps I saw in New Zealand last year! Podocarpaceae is a really cool family of conifers found mostly in southern hemisphere. The cones of some species are similar looking to those of yews, with scales that are brightly colored, fleshy and sweet, adapted to being eaten and dispersed by birds. Though they sometimes look very similar, yews and podocarps are not closely related. 

Podocarpaceae is basically the Southern Hemisphere version of Pinaceae (pines, firs, spruces and relatives). Pinaceae is almost entirely endemic to the Northern Hemisphere, with just one species, Pinus merkusii, barely crossing into the Southern Hemisphere in Southeast Asia. Podocarpaceae crosses into the Northern Hemisphere in Southern Asia, Subsaharan Africa and from northern South America into Central America. It is a classic example of the Antarctic Flora, which evolved on Gondwana, when South America, Africa, Australia, New Zealand and Antarctica were all connected around 200 million years ago. As the continents drifted apart to their present day locations, they carried with them their linages of Podocarpaceae which they still harbor today, except for Antarctica, whose members finally were extinguished there less than 10 million years ago. 

As the planet begins to warm back up thanks to us naked apes, Antarctic will once again be able to support coastal forests of podocarps and southern beech in the maybe not so distant future! 

I was lucky enough to see all the genera of Podocarpaceae native New Zealand while I was there, so here’s a sample of one species from each!

1. Podocarpus nivalis
2. Phyllocladus alpinus
3. Dacrydium cupressinum
4. Halocarpus biformis
5. Manoao colensoi
6. Dacrycarpus dacrydioides
7. Lepidothamnus laxifolius
8. Prumnopitys ferruginea

Eriogonum shockleyi, one of the Great Basin’s most iconic buckwheats! Oönopsis wardii, definitely one of the most obscure plants I’ve seen in awhile! This species is nearly endemic to Wyoming, with just one occurrence known across the border in Colorado. It grows only on selenium rich barrens and is a selenium accumulator, making it toxic to most herbivores. There are also Astragalus species that are selenium accumulators, and it was interesting to note that both Oönopsis and those Astragalus reek of the same snake musk-like odor, indicative of selenium in the plant tissues! It is so powerful and nauseating that the small sample I collected made my car reek of it for a couple days. It’s handy that things that smell terrible are often poisonous, which dissuades us from eating such things. 

Humans (and pretty much all living things) require extremely small amounts of selenium which is a component of a few vital enzymes, but in higher amounts it causes selenosis, a real nasty disease that can cause your hair and fingernails to fall out, neurological damage and eventually death. Not that anyone is about to eat Oönopsis… just a fun fact!

Gentiana latidens, the Balsam Mountain Gentian! This awesome large flowered bottle gentian is endemic to North Carolina where it only grows at higher elevations of the Blue Ridge Mountains, often in wet seepy areas full of other cool plants. The Appalachian Mountains are ancient and low enough that they were spared glaciation and permanent snow cover for most of the range during the ice ages, which has allowed species to accumulate and diversify over the eons, which is why the southern Appalachians are one of the most biodiverse areas of the United States. I’m hoping to get back in there some more this fall, especially as the rain brings out the mushrooms!

The high southern Appalachian Mountains are a sight to behold. Open rocky outcrops here are covered in flowering Rhododenrons in the summer and fruiting Sorbus americana in the fall. An almost tropical look! Sorbus americana fruits are very showy to attract birds, which eat and disperse the seeds. They are very sour and astringent raw (I didn’t think they tasted too bad), but become sweeter after a frost. The fruits contain parasorbic acid when raw, which can cause kidney damage in larger amounts, but when cooked it is broken down to harmless sorbic acid. They can then be used in things like pies and jam.

In the Appalachian mountains it is restricted to mostly the higher ranges, but becomes more widespread the farther north you go. There are a handful of Sorbus species in North America, but the genus is much more diverse in Eurasia. 

Fruit can be just as showy or showier than flowers!

Chelone glabra, white turtlehead! This cool late bloomer is one of four species in the genus Chelone, who’s name comes from Greek for turtle. The genus is endemic to eastern North America, with its closest relative, the strange monotypic, Nothochelone nemorosa, endemic to the mountains of the Pacific Northwest. Chelone and Nothochelone are close relatives to the extremely species rich genus Penstemon. These genera are all members of family Plantaginaceae in the tribe Cheloneae. 

The falling leaves, smell of decomposers at work, partially cloudy skies and mild temperatures are all my favorite things about fall. Bright colors all around!

Frasera gypsicola, the Sunnyside green gentian! This rare desert gentian is the most diminutive of all members of the genus Frasera, as far as I know. It is endemic to the middle of the Great Basin in eastern Nevada and just across the border into western Utah. Despite its Latin name, it doesn’t actually grow on gypsum soils, but tends to grow on isolated white ashy outcrops or calcareous barrens in the bottoms of the Great Basin valleys. These habitats are also full of other edaphic endemic plants like Artemisia pygmaea, Lepidium nanum, Eriogonum shockleyi, Eriogonum howellianum and others. You don’t really think I’d gentians being in the desert do you!?

Driving past a salt lake in the Great Basin of southeast Oregon in July, I could see strange and vast, black bands out in the lake, alternating with the white salt crusts and blue water. I had a hunch on what the black bands might be… but could there really be that many? So I used my drone to explore the mystery. 

Yes, my friends, the black bands are all flies. Billions and billions of brine flies! These awesome little flies are in the family Ephydridae, and this species lives out its entire life around desert salt lakes. Their larvae are aquatic, grazing on the abundant algae and bacteria growing in the warm, shallow, salty waters of the lake. The larvae then pupate and emerge from the water as the black colored flies you see en masse here. Their shed pupae are so numerous that they line the shores of the lake in huge mats. The adult flies appear to feed in very shallow water along the lakeshore and shallow water around the salt crusts, concentrating them into black bands where the water is just the right depth for them to feed. 

I was able to walk down to the shore of the lake which was a sinking sort of mud, but which hosted a sample of the flies in a small band along the wet shore. Here I could investigate them close up and see them all feeding with their little butts up in the air. As far as flies go I think they’re really quite cute! 

Flying out to the huge populations and realizing what they were had me cackling on the side of the lake. How absolutely insane and incredible that way out here in the Oregon desert there is this wonder of nature unfolding. Humble algae and bacteria are being transformed into an unimaginable quantity of animal biomass in the form of flies. Which then are easy food for dragonflies, damselflies, spiders, birds, lizards, rodents, etc. which then disperse and poop or end up being eaten themselves by predators farther away from the lake, taking nutrients from this under appreciated habitat into the surrounding region. 

I think this was one of my favorite encounters of the entire year. Here’s to the humble brine fly! 

#Ephydridae #brinefly #brineflies #shorefly #shoreflies #entomology #insects #insect #arthropodsanonymous

Earlier this year I was excited to visit a very special place in Southern California where four endemic plants grow on carbonate rich rocky soil in a small geographic area. 

Some great news too! These plants and their habitat have been federally protected from mining! All four of these are listed California Rare Plant Rank (CRPR) 1B.1, the most threatened listing in California, and all are federally endangered except Erigeron parishii which is federally threatened. 

The isolated carbonate rock they grow on has a very different soil chemistry compared to the surrounding rock types, and these plants have adapted to this special chemistry, allowing them to grow with less competition. This carbonate rock is also attractive to miners, who can mine it to make cement and other industrial products. The problem with this is these plants can and only grow on this substrate, which has already been heavily mined in the surrounding area. They can’t be anywhere else. But carbonate rock can be mined in other less sensitive places. So it is extremely good news to hear these beautiful wildflowers and their ecosystem, millions of years in the making, will be preserved for future generations to admire, instead of the shortsighted quick cash grab which could destroy them completely. 

Here are these beautiful endangered plants!

Photos 4-5: Erigeron parishii

Dedeckera eurekensis, July gold! This very rare and monotypic shrub is closely related to Eriogonum, and is endemic to Inyo and Mono Counties in California. It exists as just a few scattered populations in the Whites, Inyos and mountains of northern Death Valley. 

The huge snowpack and heavy spring and summer rains in the Owens Valley this year had this population absolutely exploding with flowers. Even though they  can be covered in flowers, this species rarely sets seed, and seedlings have never been observed in the wild (or so I read). This species is thought be a relict from the ice ages, when it likely had a larger geographic range which has since contracted to its present rather small populations. 

Like many rare plants, in the right habitat it can be abundant, as it was all over this steep hillside in the White Mountians! It can easily be distinguished from the genus Eriogonum by its lack of an involucre, a tube formed by the six fused flower bracts. Dedeckera’s flower bracts are not fused together. 

A really cool plant to get to know! I would have gotten better photos, but there was a pretty wicked lightning storm starting as I snapped these!

Loeseliastrum matthewsii, desert calico! This population growing in cinders of the Big Pine Volcanic Field in the Owens Valley had unusually yellowish colored flowers vs the more typical pink or purplish flowers, but otherwise the plants looked normal. 

Loeseliastrum is in the family Polemoniaceae, members of which usually have radially symmetrical flowers, though some genera like Loeseliastrum have bilaterally symmetrical flowers. The genera Ipomopsis and Eriastrum even has some species with radially symmetric flowers and other species that are bilaterally symmetric. When it comes to flower shape, going from radial to bilateral or vice versa is not always a huge morphological or evolutionary jump, and many genera and families can vary in this respect!

Escobaria vivipara, the spiny star cactus, growing on a limestone knoll just west of Great Basin National Park in eastern Nevada. This beautiful cactus is one of the most widespread species in North America, being found from California to Minnesota and Mexico to Canada. It is also one of the most (maybe the most?) cold hardy cactus in the world. In this part of Nevada, temperatures range from 101°F (38°C) in summer to -30°F (-34.5°C) in the winter. Brutally cold, but this species also grows in the Great Plains of southern Canada, and near Regina, Saskatchewan, where this species is found, temperatures have reached -50°F (-58°C)!!! Now the cacti probably survive this with the help of winter snow cover, but even still it is incredibly impressive! Cacti are really masters of aridity, and not necessarily  the heat, though the often excel in hot environments too. In Regina, Saskatchewan, the hottest temp recorded was 111°F (43.9°C), meaning temperatures in that region can range 161°F (72°C)!! 

This is one hardy cactus!

Rhinotropis subspinosa, the spiny milkwort! This cool species is found scattered across the Great Basin, and it was having an excellent year with the heavy precipitation. If you’re from the eastern US, seeing members of Polygalaceae in the desert probably seems odd as they’re mostly wetland plants in the east! Out here they’re usually spiny perennials or shrubs. Members of Polygalaceae are found on every continent except Antarctica in all different environments from deserts, wetlands and tropical rainforests and everything in between. 

Polygalaceae is in the order Fabales, with just 3 other families: Fabaceae, Surianaceae and Quillajaceae. Fabaceae is of course an enormous family with tens of thousands of species, Polygalaceae has a little under 1000 species and the other two families have just 10 species combined. An interesting lineage of plants Fabales are! Some clades became incredibly diverse and others have just hung on to existence.

Gossypium hirsutum, upland cotton! This species is the wild ancestor of cultivated cotton! It is native to Mexico, Central America and probably here in southern Florida as well. It has been cultivated for its fibers for at least 5500 years, and is the same species that is cultivated in the southern United States. Something I think is real interesting is that this species in the wild is a woody shrub, but is grown as an annual crop.

Many people are surprised to learn that cotton is in the family Malvaceae, the mallows, having large showy flowers that look like Hibsicus, which is also in the mallow family. Other well known plants in the mallow family include chocolate, okra, durian, hollyhocks and lindens!

Salvinia minima, water spangles! This cool plant is a floating aquatic fern! Though it is really cool, it is an invasive species in the Everglades. The top of the fronds are covered in hairs that prevent it from becoming wet. When submerged a sheen of air is captured by them. This helps the fern stay afloat right on the surface of the water. 

In photo 3 you can see Salvinia minima growing with a species of Azolla, another floating aquatic fern (see photo 4 for a closeup of the Azolla). Salvinia and Azolla are the only two genera in the family Salviniaceae. Salviniaceae and Marsileaceae are the only two families which make up the order Salviniales. 

Members of Marsileaceae are also all aquatic or semiaquatic ferns, the genera included being Marsilea, the water clovers (see photo 5 for Marsilea vestita), Regnellidium, the monotypic two leaf water clover, which is endemic to Brazil and Argentina and Pilularia, the pillworts (see photo 6 for Pilularia americana). 

This ancient clade of aquatic ferns has been around for over 200 million years, not long after the first dinosaurs evolved! How I would love to walk around in a swamp in the late Triassic, 75 million years before mosquitoes existed!!! With the proviso that the dinos don’t fuck me up.

Diplacus rupicola, the Death Valley monkeyflower! Blooming today, December 20th.

The more time I spend in the Mojave, I’m coming to learn that, at least at lower elevations, seasons don’t matter all that much to many of the plant species that grow here. They will go ahead and bloom almost any time of the year as long as there has been lots of rain. Such is the case here with Diplacus rupicola, responding to the torrential rain from Hurricane Hilary back in August. Diplacus rupicola typically blooms from February to June, but being hardy to both heat and cold, it can apparently burst into flower if it gets enough water in the winter. 

All these plants in the lower elevations of the Mojave can do this because water is really their only limiting growth factor. They have all the light they could possibly want, plenty of mineral nutrients, and it warms up pretty fast, even on a winter day out here. Many of the annuals and perennials are also capable of withstanding freezing temperatures. Desert plants are just the toughest things out there. 

Really a treat today to see dozens of big healthy flowering Diplacus rupicola in the early morning light!

The Florida cottonmouth (Agkistrodon conanti)! This cool snake was coiled up right next to the Dodge Challenger after we got back from a little hike along the swamp! Then it slowly moved away and perched on a palmetto frond and watched us, but never displayed any aggressive behavior. 

Cottonmouths, also called water moccasins, get a bad reputation, but really aren’t that scary. They are venomous, but like all snakes they try to escape first, and even if they stand their ground, they give warning by opening their white mouths which stands out against the background vegetation. I found this out first hand in Florida a couple years ago when I stepped directly over a Florida cottonmouth I didn’t see and all it did was pop open its mouth and look up at me! 

Snakes don’t want to pick a fight with gigantic predators like humans, but they also don’t want to die and will defend themselves if they’re under attack. You should never kill snakes, especially if you’re out hiking around in their homes. Many people that get bit do so by trying to kill them or try picking them up. 

Cottonmouths have to be the top misidentified snakes in North America. There are dozens of species of non-venomous water snakes throughout North America, and all of them get mistaken for cottonmouths. People tend to think that any snake that touches water is a cottonmouth. All my life growing up in Ohio and West Virginia people freaked out and killed every snake they saw in or near water and bragged about how they killed a cottonmouth or water moccasin, even though a 2 second google search will reveal that cottonmouths don’t live in Ohio or West Virginia or even within 100 miles of either of these states. 

Knowledge is power! The more I see potentially dangerous animals like venomous snakes, alligators, bears, mountain lions, etc. the more I love and respect them and the less scary they are. I love sharing the world with animals like these. It would be so much worse off without them.

Eumaeus atala, the Atala! This beautiful butterfly is only found in Florida in the United States, but also Cuba, the Bahamas and some other Caribbean islands. 

It was thought to be extinct in the US for a few decades until it was rediscovered on a barrier island near Miami. How it came to be so rare is an all too familiar story and lesson in exploitation of natural resources. 

The only native host plant for this species is the coontie (Zamia integrifolia), the only cycad native to the United States. This cycad has been a staple food for indigenous people in south Florida for thousands of years. Even though it is very poisonous, it can be detoxified through a rigorous process of grinding, soaking, rinsing, fermenting and drying the roots to produce a high quality, edible starch. 

In the 1800s this process was industrialized and mills popped up in Florida to mass produce what was marketed as “Florida Arrowroot” and the starch was then sold to locals, the US Army and to Europe. These mills relied entirely on plants dug up from the wild. So completely predictably and unsurprisingly wild coontie populations collapsed in Florida by the early 1900s, taking with them all animals that relied on them like the Atala butterfly. 

The recovery of this species in Florida though, is a great story of hope and the benefits of growing locally native plants where you live. The coontie has become a popular native ornamental plant in Florida, as it is a beautiful, hardy tropical looking cycad. The abundance of these on the urban and suburban landscape as well as some other related, though not native cycads, has given this butterfly large food sources, and because the butterfly accumulates the carcinogenic and neurotoxic chemical cycasin that it gets from eating its host plants, it is rarely eaten by predators. This has allowed the species to bounce back from extinction and it is now thriving everywhere from the pine rocklands of the Everglades to downtown Miami! 

Plant native plants!

Langloisia setosissima ssp. punctata, spotted Langloisia! This beautiful little desert wildflower was blooming in small, but surprisingly dense patches in the Mojave near Barstow a few weeks ago! This subspecies can be so variable in how spotted the flowers are and the corolla can range anywhere from bright white to completely purple and everywhere in between. In any shade, it’s one of the most intricate flowers in the desert!

Vittaria lineata, the shoestring fern! This very unusual looking epiphytic fern could easily be mistaken at a glance for a grass, but a careful inspection of the underside of a frond reveals two parallel lines which are where spores are produced. 

It’s seems to be very fond of growing from the trunks of palmettos in thick humid swamps, at least in southern Florida. 

I’ve walked right past these ferns multiple times on previous trips to the Everglades and Big Cypress, but this time they were on my radar and they were easy to find! I surely still had and have some plant blindness to the vegetation in the southeastern US! 

I love how many forms ferns can take that deviate from what I learned ferns looked like as a kid. They’re not just a triangular green unfurling frondy thing that grows in moist forests, but can be grasslike (Vittaria or Asplenium septentrionale), tiny floating aquatic plants (Azolla), aquatic four leaf clover looking things (Marsilea), baked desert plants (Myriopteris parryi), or even 60 foot tall trees (Cyathea medullaris). Having been on the earth for around 360 million years, they’ve had plenty of time adapt to the planet’s changing landscapes!
